\lx  𑜀𑜠
\lxx  k;
\ph  ka
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  crow
\de  crow 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  কাউৰী
\gr  কাউৰী
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 2r8
\xe  𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜀𑜠 𑜓𑜢𑜆𑜫 𑜄𑜥 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  mnq y[q nj k; dipq tU fEkq /
\xn  man jang nai ka dip tu phvk
\xr  'He will then get a live white crow.'
\xv  তেওঁ তেতিয়া এটা বগা কাউৰী হিচাপে জীৱন লাভ কৰিব ।

\xe  𑜁𑜧 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜣 𑜀𑜠 𑜍𑜥 𑜃𑜪𑜡 𑜽

\xn  khau chang min mv tuk ti ka ru nam na
\xr  'They then flew and came down to the head (of the river).'
\xv  সিহঁত তেতিয়া উৰি গৈছিল আৰু (নদীখনৰ) মূৰৈল নামি

\xn  song ra tak tak ba ka kan mv ban nai
\xr  'We two will speak tak tak at this time of day.'
\xv 
\gn  သွင် (ႁႃး) တၵ်းတၵ်း ဝႃႈ ၵႃႈ ၵၼ် မိူဝ်ႈဝၼ်း ၼႆႉ ။

\xex  A] t[q xoj fEkq hU fEkq mU fEkq pitqhnq fEkq pitqnoj fEkq kj fEkq k;ek] fEkq nukqtU en] a

\xr  'offer a white buffalo, a white cow, a white pig, a white goose, a white duck, a white chicken, a white pigeon and a dove'

 কপৌ উতসৰগা কৰা ।

\lx  𑜀𑜥
\lxx  kU
\ph  ku
\hm  2
\ps  n.
\ge  perfume
\de  perfume derived from a civet
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  সুগিনধ দ্ৰৱয়
\gr  সুগিনধ দ্ৰৱয়
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B116
\xe  𑜃𑜪 𑜋𑜥 𑜃𑜪 𑜁𑜠 𑜃𑜪 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜠 𑜃𑜪𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜨𑜀𑜫𑜐𑜠 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜀𑜥 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜋𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜋𑜠𑜉𑜣 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜉𑜣𑜍𑜧 𑜄𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜇𑜩 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜋𑜢 𑜏𑜠𑜉𑜣 𑜉𑜀𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜤𑜆𑜫 𑜉𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜪𑜤 𑜼
\xex  nM cU nM x; nM fE[q nM nE[q x; nMvE[q mokqN; hoM kU hoM cnq hoM c;mI hoM mIr] tiNq fj hoM ci s;mI mkq bnq kupq mkq suM a
\xn  nam chu nam kha nam phvng nam nvng kha nam thvng mok nya hom ku hom chan hom cha mi hom mi rav ten phai hom chi sa mi
 mak ban kup mak sum 
\xr  'milk, 'kha' water, honey, 'kha' tea, curd, various fragrant flowers, good-smelling torches, fragrant candles, fragrant chi incense, sweet
 fruit, tarty fruit'
\xv 
\notes  In Terwiel and Ranoo's translation, the word <ku>, 'perfume derived from a civet' is subsumed in the phrase 'various fragrant
 flowers', the translation of <mokya hom ku hom chan hom chami
 hom'. A better translation might be 'fragrant flowers, fragrant civet
 perfume, strong fragrance and 'chami' fragrance'.
\dt  10/May/2011

\xe  𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜁𑜩𑜡 𑜉𑜧 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜀𑜥 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜂(𑜉𑜫) 𑜀𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  em] xja m] eka c[q poj kU xi[q [(mq) kotq xunq mE[q /

\xex  hnq t[q pnq sI pinq riw tikq k[q eka b[q bU eka kI hM xU si[qu AU /
\xn  han tang pan si pin riu tik kang ko bang bu ko ki ham khu seng u 
\xr  'Saw the pansi orchid tapering and breaking the cluster and putting down (new feelers) and spreading, opening when nearly ripe like a
 mighty diamond cluster.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁၼ် တင်း ပၼ်းသေး ပဵၼ် ႁဵဝ်း တႅၵ်ႇ ၵၢင် ၵေႃ ဝၢင်း ပူ ၵေႃႈ ၵီႈ ႁၢမ်ႇ ၶူဝ်ႈ သႅင် ဢူ ။
\sn  2
\ge  community
\de  community
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၵေႃ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 9r6
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜫𑜡 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜧 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜽
\xex  h] mnq hiaq t[q pE[q pkq co[q n] eka /
\xn  hav man hit tang pvng pak chong nav ko 
\xr  'Make him into the one who is the form and the rule of the community.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁ်ႂႈ မၼ်း ႁဵတ်း တင်း ပိူင် ပၵ်း ၸွင်ႈ ၼ်ႂး ၵေႃ ။

\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xn  pav lai lak ko khvng kvng pha pin pau bang nang 
\xr  'Wearing silk and different things suitable for the king, things that are hanging down extended to the brim.'
\xv 
\gn  ပႂ်း လၢႆႈ လၢၵ်ႇ ၵေႃ ၶိူင်ႈ ၵိုင်ႇ ၾႃႉ ပဵၼ် ပဝ်း ဝၢင်း ၼၢင်ႈ ။

\lxx  k]
\ph  kav
\hm  8
\ps  adv.
\ge  near
\de  near
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  কাষত
\gr  কাষত
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B33
\xe  𑜎𑜀𑜫𑜃𑜣 𑜀𑜠𑜏𑜧 𑜋𑜪 𑜊𑜥 𑜀𑜧 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜥 𑜈𑜄𑜫 𑜱 𑜊𑜥 𑜀𑜧 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  lkqnI k;s] cM yU k] n]w xokq mU btq z yU k] n]w xokq c[q a
\xn  lak ni ka sav cham yu kav nau khok mu bat 1 yu kav nau khok chang
\xr  'In the 30th year of the cycle for a moment it was near the Pig Enclosure Stars and [then went] close by the Elephant Enclosure
 Stars'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜧𑜰𑜫
\lxx  k]w
\ph  kau
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  spider
\de  spider
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၵၢဝ်
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 2v3
\xe  𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜱 𑜊𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜇𑜥 𑜀𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜄𑜥 𑜐𑜧 𑜽
\xex  poj pE[q z yinq pinq cM fU k]w xM tU N] /
\xn  poi pvng lvng jin pin cham phu kau kham tu nyav 
\xr  'And seventhly, he was turned to a golden spider with a large body.'
\xv 
\gn  ပွႆး ပိူင် ၼိုင်ႈ ယဵၼ်း ပဵၼ် ၸမ်း ၽူႈ ၵၢဝ် ၶမ်း တူဝ် ယ်ႂႇ ။
\se  𑜀𑜧
\sex  k]
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 1v-13
\dn  𑜉𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜀𑜫
\dnx  ema kow rkq
\dr  mo ko rak
\dv  মকৰাক
\gr  মকৰাক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv   
\se  𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫
\sex  kow
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၵၢဝ်
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 2v8
\xe  𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜈𑜡 𑜍𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜣 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜩 𑜽
\xex  fa kow tkq ba ruw mI lukq pinq xj /
\xn  pha kau tak ba ru mi luk pin khai 
\xr  'The spider came brightly to have a child who became an egg.'
\xv 
\gn  ၾႃႉ ၵၢဝ် တၵ်း မႃး ႁိူဝ်ႈ မီး လူၵ်ႈ ပဵၼ် ၶႆႇ ။
\se  𑜀𑜧𑜨
\sex  ko]
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၵၢဝ်
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 15v6
\xe  𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜧𑜨 𑜈𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜒𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 
\xex  mnq c[q xotq t[q s[q ko] bEnq Aonq t[q 
\xn  man chang khot tang sang kau biun on tang 
\xr  'He will then take away and order his spider (to go) in front ...'
\xv 
\gn  မၼ်း ၸင်ႇ ၶွတ်ႇ တင်း သင်ႇ ၵၢဝ် (မၼ်း) ဢွၼ် တၢင်း 
\se  𑜀𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫
\sex  ko]w
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၵၢဝ်
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 3v7
\xe  𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜊𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜁𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  xi[q ko]w xoM yinq pinq tunq xEw xoM xo[q si[q /
\xn  khing kau kham jin pin tun khv kham khong sing
\xr  'The gold spider then turned into a golden creeper, a thing of power.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶိင်း ၵၢဝ် ၶမ်း ယဵၼ်း ပဵၼ် တူၼ်ႈ ၶိူဝ်း ၶမ်း ၶွင် သႅင် ။  
\notes

\xe  𑜉𑜧𑜨 𑜇𑜨𑜡 𑜀𑜥 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜪 𑜽
\xex  mo] foa kU t[q pkq xnq kM /
\xn  mau pha ku tang pak khan kam
\xr  'You please speak some words.'
\xv  অনুগ্হ কৰি কিবা এটা কওঁক ।
\gn 
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 1v1
\xe  𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜐𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜣 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜁𑜦𑜡 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜏𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜏𑜤𑜄𑜫 --𑜄𑜫 𑜏𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜪 𑜽
\xex  n[q eka N[q mI pE[q sI exa xoM sonq mw fa sutq --tq stq kM /
\xn  nang ko nyang mi pvng si kho khom son mau pha sut ... t sat kam 
\xr  'The lady did nothing wrong, she did not abandon the teaching (of the Lord) ... bringing his words to an end.'
\xv 
\gn  ၼၢင်း ၵေႃႈ ယင်ႊ မီး ပိူင်ႈ သေ ၶေႃႈ ၶႂၢမ်း သွၼ် မဝ်ႇ ၽႃႈ သုတ်း ... သၢတ်ႈ ၵမ်း ။

\xn  tang ka kon pha kam ko chang tak man poi tik pin nang 
\xr  'And the heap of brown stones then are spread out and he will break them to make woman.'

\xv 
\gn  တင်း ၵႃႈ ၵွၼ်ႈ ၽႃ ၵမ်ႇ ၵေႃႈ ၸင်ႇ တၢၵ်ႇ မၼ်း ပွႆး တႅၵ်ႇ ပဵၼ် ၼၢင်း ။

\xe  𑜇𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜝𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜀𑜃𑜣 𑜁𑜪𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜣𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜣𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜈𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜧 𑜼
\xex  fa c[q pRu[q knq lknI xMmE[q pIpnq pIknq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn  pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham nin to tav
\xr  'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down

\lx  𑜀𑜪𑜤

\xex  t[qk; fa kuM ni[q n[q lEtq pinq cM tkq nitq nM na a
\xn  tang ka pha kum ning nang lvt pin cham tak nit nam na
\xr  'the whole sky bechame overcast, red like blood and then sunshine was excessive'
\xv  গোটেই আকাশখন তেজৰ দেৰ ৰঙীণ হৈ গোমা হৈছিল আৰু সূৰুযৰ কিৰণ অতিমাত্ৰা হৈছিল ।
\notes 
\dt  01/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜀𑜫
\lxx  kkq
\ph  kak
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  throne
\de  throne 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  সিংহাসন
\gr  সিংহাসন
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 2v5
\xe  𑜍𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  riu[q x[q kkq /
\xn  rvng khang kak
\xr  'Bright at the side of the throne.'
\xv  সিংহাসনৰ উজ্জ্বল ফাল ।
\notes  Nabin Shaym suggested that the word kak might mean 'throne'. Chaichuen Khamdaengyodtai observed that in Thai Mau <khaak>
 means a 'stand', which could have been extended to mean a throne.

\hm  2
\ps  n.
\ge  chin

\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  থুতৰীক
\gr  থুতৰীক

\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B36
\xe  𑜎𑜀𑜫𑜃𑜣 𑜃𑜆𑜫𑜉𑜤𑜄𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜊𑜥 𑜇𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  lkqnI npqmutq cM yU fi[q n]w k[q a
\xn   lak ni nap mut cham yu phing nau kang
\xr  'In the 32nd year of the cycle it was alongside the (Pig) Chin Stars.'
\xv  বিত্ৰছ বৰ্ষ চক্ৰত এইেটা (গাহিৰ) থুতৰী তাৰকা সিহেত আিছল ।

\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 13r1
\xe  𑜉𑜢 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜇𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜩𑜤 𑜌𑜧𑜨 𑜍𑜪𑜨 𑜽
\xex  mi t[q siNq fu[q [iukq k[q lju vo] roM /
\xn  mi tang sen phung ngvk kang laai thau rom

\xv 
\gn  မီး တင်း သႅၼ် ၽုင် ငိူၵ်ႈ ၵၢင်း လၢႆး ထဝ်ႇ ႁွမ်း ။

\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xr  'Like logs floating in the waters of the Ganges.'
\xv

\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xn  mav nang to ma nai ngin sin ming rong khrang phrang nam kung ka 
\xr  '(The prince said), “You oh lady have come to hear the 100,000 insects calling from the banks of the River Ganges.'
\xv

\dr 
\dv

\xn  pin ngvi phraang kung ka

\xv 
\gn  ပဵၼ် လူၺ်ႈ ၾင်ႇ ၵင်းၵႃႇ ။

\gv  ၵၼ်

\xe  𑜁𑜧 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜑𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜲 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜌𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  x] poj h[q knq po[q knq 2 koj vukq /
\xn  khav poi hang kan pong kan song koi thuk
\xr  'They consulted each other for a suitable solution.'
\xv  তেওঁেলােক এটা উপযুক্ত সমাধানৰ বােব পৰস্পৰক সোধ-েপাছকিৰিছল ।
\gn 
\notes  also Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A1
\dt  25/Jan/2013

\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 13v7
\xe  𑜀𑜣 𑜑𑜪 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜥 𑜎𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽

\lx  𑜀𑜃𑜫
\lxx  knq
\ph  kan
\hm  4
\ps  n.
\ge  kneeling
\de  kneeling
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 31v-12
\dn  𑜒𑜡 𑜌𑜥 𑜀𑜠 𑜍𑜣 𑜊𑜥 𑜒𑜀𑜫
\dnx  Aa vU k; rI yU Akq
\dr  a thu ka ri ju ak
\dv  আঁঠু কাঢি় যোৱাক
\gr  আঁঠু কাঢি় যোৱাক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  This was originally translated as 'crawling' which would correspond to Shan kaan: However Bibek Borgohain pointed out that a thu ka ri
 ju a means 'kneeling' rather than 'crawling' The meaning of /a thu ka
 ri ju ak/ is t'o move by keeling', which in one word is 'crawling.'
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫
\lxx  kinq
\ph  kin
\hm  2
\ps  v.
\ge  swear.oath
\de  swear oath
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  শপত লবৰ
\gr  শপত লবৰ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 3v1
\xe  𑜀𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜩 𑜐𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜽
\xex  ko]w eka puj kinq sj Notq fa /
\xn  kau ko pai kin sai nyot pha
\xr  'I also go to swear an oath to the line of the top of the sky.'
\xv  মইও আকাশৰ শীৰ্ষ দিশত এটা শপত লব যাওঁ ।

\dt  29/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜠
\lxx  kinq x;
\ph  kin kha
\ps  n
\ge  small.medicine.plant
\de  small medicinal plant
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 39r-5
\dn  𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜥 𑜍𑜥 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜐𑜫
\dnx  eha rU rU mENq
\dr  ho ru ru mvi
\dv  সৰু ৰুমৈক
\gr  সৰু ৰুমৈক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  In Shan the word ken mav refers to the part that joins a leaf to the stem, so kin kha might refer to the joining of a branch to the tree.
 This would accord with the Assamese word horu that is used here.
 According to Junaram Sangbun Phukan, there is a plant/shrub
 named /ho ru ru moi/
\dt  29/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  kinq mE[q
\ph  kin mvng
\ps  comp.
\ge  rule
\de  rule, to; enjoy the revenue of the country, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  শাসন কৰা, দেশৰ খাজনা গ্ৰহন কৰা
\gr  শাসন কৰা, দেশৰ খাজনা গ্ৰহন কৰা
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B149
\xe  𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜥 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜥 𑜐𑜧 𑜇𑜥 𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜥 𑜁𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜼
\xex  t[q Anq fU xEw fU N] fU kinq mE[q fU x] t[q mE[q cM a
\xn  tang an phu khv phu nyav phu kin mvng phu khav tang mvng cham
\xv  ক্ষমতাশালী, সম্ভ্ৰান্ত আৰু শাসকসকলোৰ বোবে একেলগে ।
\notes  The translation in Terwiel and Ranoo (1992) does not explicitly translate thecompound <kin mvng>. A more literal translation would
 be 'as for the powerful, who use the revenue of the county ...'
\dt  29/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪

\ph  kon kham
\ps  n.
\ge  horse
\de  horse
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  ঘোঁৰা
\gr  ঘোঁৰা
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 1r2
\xe  𑜎𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜥 𑜆𑜩 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜎𑜥 𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  el] nU pj siNq lunq konq xM lU Anq /
\xn  le nu pai sen lun kon kham lu an
\xr  'Looked out at more than one lakh male elephants and horses that cannot be counted.' 
\xv  লক্ষাধিক মতা হাতী আৰু ঘাঁৰালৈ চাইছিল যিবোৰ অগণনীয় ।
\notes  Probably literally 'heap of gold'.
\dt  01/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫
\lxx  kEnq
\ph  kvn
\hm  5
\ps  v.
\ge  many
\de  to be many
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv  বহুত
\gr  বহুত
\gv  ၵိုၼ်း
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 3v4
\xe  𑜃𑜩 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜑𑜩 𑜀𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜽
\xex  nj eka em] n[q mE[q eka hj ktq kEnq niuw fa /
\xn  nai ko me nang mvng ko hai kat kvn nv pha
\xr  'Then the Queen was crying, grinding her teeth continuously, on the bedding.'
\xv  তেতিয়া ৰাণীগৰাকীয়ে শোৱাপাটীত বিহ কান্দিছিল আৰু অহৰহ দাঁতেবাৰ কৰছিছিল ।
\notes  In this example the word that was glossed as 'many' is translated as 'continuously'
\dt  01/Aug/2011

\xr  'The sky (God) sighed as if he had fallen from a hill, from a cliff or into a valley.'
\xv

\lx  𑜀𑜨𑜆𑜫

\sn  2
\ge  palmful
\de  palmful

\dn  𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜦𑜡 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫

\notes  /boi kop pu lin pu thao rau/ is a phrase for paying respest to forefathers according to both Junaram Sangbun Phukan and Medini
 Mohan, and is used in poems and songs

\lx  𑜀𑜢𑜉𑜫
\lxx  kimq
\ph  kim
\hm  1
\ps  n
\ge 
\de   
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 42r-8
\dn  𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜠 𑜀𑜠 𑜉𑜢𑜆𑜫
\dnx  kow r; k; mipq
\dr  kau ra ka mip
\dv  কাউৰা কামিপ
\gr  কাউৰা কামিপ
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Junaram Sangbun Phukan suggested that the split bamboo used for tying a bamboo wall of a house is called /ka mi/. In Ahom Lexicon
 page 168 the meaning of /ho ra ka mik/ is given as a piece of split
 rafter.'
\dt  22/Oct/2012

\xe  𑜀𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜝𑜣 𑜒𑜝𑜣𑜠 𑜇𑜥 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜽

\lx  𑜀𑜄𑜫
\lxx  ktq
\ph  kat
\hm  2
\ps  n.
\ge  market
\de  market
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 48v-3
\dn  𑜑𑜠 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  h; tokq
\dr  ha tok
\dv  হাটক
\gr  হাটক
\gv  ၵၢတ်ႇ
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B51
\xe  𑜎𑜦 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜎𑜦 𑜏𑜧 𑜆𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜩 𑜀𑜄𑜫 𑜏𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜀𑜫𑜉𑜥 𑜉𑜀𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜩 𑜼
\xex  el mEw k; el s] pi[q ninq sI eka nj ktq sunq mkqmU mkq bnq eka nj a
\xn  le mv ka le sav ping nin chi ko nai kat sun mak mu mak ban ko nai
\xr  'went and stayed there, that year it was a good time to bake bricks, and also a good time for vegetable, areca palm and fruit gardens.'
\xv  গৈিছল আৰু তাত থািকিছল, সেই বছৰেটা ইটা বেনাৱাৰ বােব ভাল সময় আিছল আৰু পাচিল, তােমাল আৰু ফলৰ বািগছাৰ
 বােবও ভাল আিছল ।
\gn 
\rf 
\notes  In their translation, Terwiel and Ranoo do not overtly include the term 'market'. An alternative translation would be '... (a good time)
 for (garden) vegetables, areca and sweet fruits' 
\dt  21/Jul/2011

\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 12r6
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜑𑜧𑜪 𑜏𑜧 𑜈𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜽
\xex  h] mEw eka t[q eboa kEw h]M s] eboa /
\xn  hav mv ko tang bo kv hem sav bo 
\xr  'Make him go to make a salt well, and prepare to stay at the well.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁႂ်ႈ မိူဝ်း ၵေႃႇ တင်း မေႃႇ ၵိူဝ် ႁႅမ်း သဝ်း မေႃႇ ။

\xr  'If I the lady am not a quiet young lady, others will slander me.'

\gn  ပေႃး ဢၼ် တူ ၼၢင်း ပဵၼ် သၢဝ် မဝ်ႇ ၼိမ် ၶိင်း ပိူၼ်ႈ ၶႃႉ ၸမ်းဝၼ်း ။
\notes 
\dt  22/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜁𑜠 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜧
\lxx  x; n[q m]
\ph  kha nang mav
\ps  n.
\ge  ?
\de  ?
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 58r-19
\dn  𑜘𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜣 𑜕𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜡
\dnx  eBa nI eKa sa
\dr  bho ni go sa
\dv  ভনি গছাক
\gr  ভনি গছাক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  The term /gosa/ appears to be a marker of a kinship term. Junaram Sangbun Phukan suggested that it is a term referring to one's own
 clan, the same clan.
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\dv

\lx  𑜁𑜡
\lxx  xa
\ph  kha
\hm  13
\ps  v.
\ge  entrust
\de  entrust, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 56v-3
\dn  𑜕𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  eKa sI borq
\dr  go si bor
\dv  গচিবৰ
\gr  গচিবৰ
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  In Assamese gosibor means to entrust someone with something with the expectation it will be returned. A cognate term gota means 'to entrust', but without the expectation of its return, such as when giving a girl in marriage. In Dehong /xaa3/ means 'to give a daughter in marriage'.
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\xe  𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜣 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜡𑜠 𑜆𑜩 𑜈𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  cw c[q xI vEkq ma; pj b[q /
\xn  chau chang khi thvk ma pai bang
\xr  'Then the prince rode the horse into the area.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  The word 'uthibor' can mean both 'get up' and 'ride'. The second meaning is appropriate here.
\dt  27/Jul/2011

\xex  pEw Anq xj fa bw dj nM pU lokq y; xj xi[q /
\xn  pv an khai pha bau dai nam pu lok ja khai khing

\xe  𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜊𑜥 𑜏𑜧 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜊𑜥 𑜄𑜪 𑜀𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜁𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  xnq eta fa eka yU s] bw yU tM k[q rw lkq koj exa koj y] /
\xn  khan to pha ko ju sav bau ju tam kang rau lak koi kho koi jav 
\xr  'And so the sky (God) was not staying in the heaven separately.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶၼ်တေႃႈ ၾႃႉ ၵေႃႈ ယူႇ သဝ်း မဝ်ႇ ယူႇ တမ်ႈ ၵၢင်ႁၢဝ် လၵ်း ၵွႆး ၶေႃ ၵွႆး ယဝ်ႉ ။
\sn  2
\ge  alone
\de  alone; lonesome
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 2v-18
\dn  𑜒𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜨𑜎𑜫 𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜣 𑜒𑜀𑜫
\dnx  eAa kolq eha rI Akq
\dr  o kol ho ri ak
\dv  অকলশৰীয়াক
\gr  অকলশৰীয়াক
\gv 
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 12r7
\xe  𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜐𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜥 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜃𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫𑜤 𑜇𑜟𑜀𑜫 𑜈𑜂𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜁𑜟𑜦𑜡 𑜽
\xex  n[q eka N[q rU si[qu no]wu ?kq b[q vEnq koj e<a /

\xv 
\gn  ၼၢင်း ၵေႃႈ ယင်ႊ ႁူႉ သႅင် လၢဝ် ၾၢၵ်ႈ ဝၢင်ႈ ထိူၼ်ႇ ၵွႆး ၶေႃ ။

\lx  𑜁𑜪
\lxx  xM
\ph  kham
\hm  10
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  pass.over
\de  pass over, to; cross, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B22
\xe  𑜇𑜧 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜡 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜋𑜪 𑜁𑜤𑜆𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜎𑜆𑜫 𑜇𑜪𑜨𑜐𑜠 𑜼
\xex  f] s[q hia n[q nj cM xupq mEw bnq xM lpq foMN; a
\xn  phav sang hit nang nai cham khup mv ban kham lap phom nya
\xr  'Whoever finds himself in these circumstances should kneel down in the evening time after sunset.'
\xv 
\xe 
\sn  2
\ge  cross.river
\de  cross a river by a boat
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 42r-20
\dn  𑜃𑜦𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜓𑜣 𑜊𑜡 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  en]w dI ya borq
\dr  nau di ja bor
\dv  নাওদি যাবৰ
\gr  নাওদি যাবৰ
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  For the phrase <kham lap phom nya>, Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:78) note that they have no parallel for this expression in any other Tai
 language. The phrase was read by Nabin Shyam as 'having crossed
 the horizon'. Shan phom is given as 'distance which the eye can see'
 (considered a yuzana in length).
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\xex  xM ni[q pinq cw n[q t[q mE[q fo; xM hiaq ebo[q ety] /
\xn  kham ning pin chau nang tang mvng pha kham hit bong te jav 
\xr  'Kham Ning is the Lord who sits (on the throne) of the country of the golden stone and is made emperor.'

\xv

\dt  15/Jun/2011

\lx  𑜁𑜪 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  xM mE[q
\ph  kham mvng
\ps  n.
\ge  kham.mvng
\de  the second of the cycles in the Ahom time-reckoning system; an astronomical phenomenon, probably Rahu (Terwiel and Ranoo
 1992:146)
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4
\xe  𑜇𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜝𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜃𑜣 𑜁𑜪 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜣 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜣 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜈𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜧 𑜼
\xex  fa c[q pRu[q knq lkq nI xM mE[q pI pnq pI knq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn  pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham nin to tav
\xr  'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down
 to the earth underneath.'
\xv

\dt  07/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜁𑜪 𑜍𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜇𑜡
\lxx  xM rotq fa
\ph  kham rot pha
\ps  pn.
\ge  PN
\de  used to refer to the king
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 2r2
\xe  𑜁𑜪 𑜍𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜆𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜩 𑜋 ... 𑜽
\xex  xM rotq fa pitq mEnq bw mj c ... /
\xn  kham rot pha pit mvn bau mai chau
\xr  'The golden one who reached the sky abandoned himself without worry.'
\xv 
\notes  It is not clear whether <Kham rot pha> is the name of the king or a form of words used to refer to the king. In this context it refers to
 the father of the hero of Ma Likha Lit.
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜁𑜂𑜫
\lxx  x[q
\ph  khang
\hm  8
\ps  n.
\ge  metal
\de  metal, defined by Terwiel and Ranoo 1992 as 'a zinc and iron alloy' [Cushing 87]
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၶၢင်
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 6v7
\xe  𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜣 𑜍𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜣 𑜋𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  emoa likq t[q fI r[q emoa x[q t[q fI cnq /
\xn  mo lik tang phi rang mo khang tang phi chan
\xr  '(It is in) an iron pot is given to the spirits of the house; in a metal pot is given to those spirits who know everything.'
\xv  (এইখিনি) লোহাৰ পাত্ৰত থকাখিনি এই ঘৰৰ আত্মাবোৰৰ বাবে, ধাতুৰ পাত্ৰত থকাখিনি সেই আত্মাৰ বাবে যি সকলো জানে ।
\gn 
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 8r5
\xe  𑜉𑜧 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜎𑜦 𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜇𑜩𑜤 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜍𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜣 𑜃𑜩𑜨 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜏𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫
\xex  m] poj el pju fju xnq pnq m; rotq kow tI noj x[q fa s] mE[q
\xn  mav poi le pai phaai khan pan ma rot kau ti noi khang pha sav mvng
\xr  'And you will roam twirling quickly, arriving to me at the metal hill of the sky, which is the post of the country.'
\xv 
\gn  မ်ႂး ပွႆး လႄႇ ပႆ ၽၢႆႈ ၶၼ် ပၼ်ႇ မႃး ႁွတ်ႈ ၵဝ် တီႈ လွႆ ၶၢင် ၾႃႉ သဝ် မိူင်း
\notes  Also in Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B125
\dt  13/Aug/2011

\xex  xo] snq ha era l]rEw l] fRnq mkqmU m] pU mkq fitq xi[q ki[q kuNq sukq kuNq xiwq kj xj Aoj cM a
\xn  khau san ha ro lav rv lav phran mak mu mav pu mak phit khing king kui suk kui khiu kai khai oi cham
\xr  'five bundles of husked rice, strong drink, distilled liquor, areca nuts, betel leaves, chillies, ginger, ripe bananas, green bananas, chickens,
 eggs and sugar cane'
\xv  পাঁচ টোপোলা তুঁহ গুছোৱা ধান, সুৰা, পাগ কৰা পানীয়, তামোল, পাণ, পকা কল, কেঁচা কল, কুকুৰা পোৱালী, কণী আৰু কুঁহিয়াৰ ।

\xr  '(Our parents) are anticipating and waiting for the two of us to speak like this, telling of the things that we (wish to) receive.'

\gn  ၵွင်း ဢၼ် [ပႂ်ႉ] သွင် ႁႃး တၢၼ်ႈ ပႅင် ၶၢၼ် ၵႂၢမ်း ႁပ်ႉ ၶိူင်ႈ တႄႉ ။
\sn  2
\ge  answer
\de  answer, to 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv 
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 7r1
\xe  𑜉𑜧𑜨 𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜥 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜪 𑜽
\xex  mo] fa kU t[q pkq xnq kM /
\xn  mau pha ku tang pak khan kam
\xr  'The prince said opened his mouth and answered her words.'
\xv  ৰাজকুমােৰ মুখ খুিলিছল আৰু তেওঁক উত্তৰ দিিছল ।
\gn 
\notes 
\dt  19/Jul/2011

\xex  kunq siNq xEnq pnq xonq sEw fo] /

\xe  𑜉𑜧 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜽
\xex  m] lkq tEw xonq mE[q xENq cw eka /
\xn  mav lak tv khon mvng khvi chau ko 
\xr  'You should use the taxes of the country that belongs to you to build it.'
\xv 
\gn  မႂ်း လၵ်း တိုဝ်း ၶွၼ် မိူင်း (ၶိူၺ်) ၶိူင်ႈ ၸဝ်ႈ ၵေႃႇ ။

\dt  28/Jul/2011

\xn  nau bang nau khok mu nau sv nau khon phai nau sa hung nau rang rv

 pronunciation of <khwan>

\ph  khap
\hm  3
\ps  n.

\de  slough

\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၶၢပ်ႈ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 7v3

\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  The word khap means 'something abandoned, left behind', as khap ngu, the snake's skin which is sloughed off '. In Shan, the phrase
 khap sing pha cha refers to a magic cloth.

\ph  khap

\ge  black-blue
\de  black-blue
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B114
\xe  𑜁𑜆𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜏𑜪 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜏𑜣 𑜍𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 : 𑜏𑜣 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜠 : 𑜏𑜣 𑜒𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  xpq fa sM fEnq xo] sI era kEw : sI tokq mnq [; : sI Ai[q a

\ge  complete

\dn  𑜒𑜥 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜎𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫

\gr  ওকলিবৰ
\gv  ၶူပ်ႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 12r2
\xe  𑜁𑜤𑜆𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜽
\xex  xupq mEw linq vEnq fa niunq nj /

\lx  𑜁𑜢𑜐𑜫
\lxx  xiNq
\ph  khen
\hm  8
\ps  v.
\ge  good
\de  be good, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၶႅၼ်ႈ
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B168
\xe  𑜊𑜡 𑜇𑜝𑜠 𑜑𑜧 𑜏𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜃𑜣 𑜁𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜼
\xex  ya fR; h] su[q sI nI xiNq koj a
\xn  ya phra hav sung si ni khen koi
\xr  'let him not forget and avert the danger, thus it will be good'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  See Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:146). The word <khen> 'good' is probably related to the comparative marker.
\dt  27/Jul/2011

\xn  mv khun tai tang pha khau phu ma nung 
\xr  'The hand of the prince just manages to touch and grab the very white cloth, and wear it.'
\xv 
\gn  မိုဝ်း ၶုၼ် တၢႆး တင်း ၽႃႈ ၶၢဝ် ၽူး မႃး ၼုင်ႈ ။

\xr  'The prince of the country heard the murmur of them calling and barking, and the sound of them enjoying, echoing up to the level of
 the bunks where the excellent pair were sleeping.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶုၼ် မိူင်း လႆႈ ငိၼ်း ဢူ သဵင် ႁွင်ႉ ၶဝ်းၶဝ်း သဵင် ၶဝ် ၵေႃႈ မူၼ်ႈ မႃး တွင်ႈ တင်း ႁၢၼ်ႉ ပွင် မႅတ်ႈ (မြၢတ်ႈ) ႁႃး ၼွၼ်း ။

\dt  27/Jul/2011

\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 10r4
\xe  𑜃𑜩 𑜂𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜄𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜧𑜨𑜃𑜫𑜤 𑜎𑜩 𑜄𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜣 𑜃𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜪𑜤 𑜆𑜣 𑜉𑜧 𑜽
\xex  nj [inq ko[q xM tEw xo]nuq lj tuNq eka sI nnq pi[q funq luM pI m] /
\xn  nai ngin kong kham tv khon khau lai tui ko si nan ping phun lum pi mav 
\xr  'Hearing the golden drum touch and make musical sounds, and many (instruments) of the same size, noisy, equal to the rain and the
 wind of the new year.'
\xv

\dt  28/Jul/2011

\xr  'Moreover, the two of them will shine, pervading the whole district, and (all) people envying them.'
\xv 
\gn  ၾၢတ်ႈတေႃႈ သွင် (သွင်ႇ) ႁိူင်း ၸွတ်ႇ ၵူႈ ၸႄႈ ၵူၼ်း ၶွႆ ၸမ်း ယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes  In the example for 'desire', the word khoi occurs as part of a proper name Ngvk Khong Khoi. The word khong is probably the same as
 the name of the river Mekhong, so the whole names means the
 'crocodile that desires the river'
\dt  28/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜂𑜣
\lxx  [I
\ph  ngi
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  second.son
\de  second son
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 3v-5
\dn  𑜒𑜦𑜧 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜐 𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜤 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  eA] tkq koj N eha ru tokq
\dr  e tak koi ho ru tok
\dv  এটাককৈ সৰুটোক
\gr  এটাককৈ সৰুটোক
\gv 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B133
\xe  𑜑𑜢𑜫𑜡 𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜒𑜩 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜣 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜼
\xex  hiaq Anq Aj xunq nEnq [I xunq bnq a
\xn  hit an ai khun nvn ngi khun ban
\xr  'make an image of the eldest lord moon, the second eldest lord sun'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  The phrase etak koi horutak means 'the smaller by one' and refers to the second son. This was misread by G.C. Baruah and Deodhai
 and Phukan as etaik koi horutak, meaning 'youngest son'

\gr  সতৰাই

\xe 
\xn

\xv 
\notes  Junaram Phukan suggests that /ho to rai/ might also mean 'to do something in a leisurely way'

\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4v5

\xn  ko svng kong te na kai vi

\se  𑜃𑜡𑜠
\sex  na;
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 3r2
\xe  𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜥 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜧 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜡𑜠 𑜽
\xex  c[q tkq sEw t[q n[q bU xoM pinq p] et] na; /
\xn  chang tak sv tang nang bu kham pin pav te na
\xr  'And then he paid the bride price for Nang Bu Kham to be his daughter-in-law.'
\xv 
\notes  This particle is very commonly used in combination with another particle, te, a grammaticalisation of the adjective 'true'

\lx  𑜃𑜡 𑜇𑜀𑜫

\ph  na phak
\ps  n.

\ge  forehead

\lx  𑜃𑜦𑜧
\lxx  en]
\ph  ne
\hm  6
\ps  part.
\ge  CONN

\so

\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 11r5
\xe  𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜑𑜧 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜊𑜥 𑜄𑜪 𑜓𑜩 𑜃𑜦𑜧 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜒𑜧 𑜑𑜠 𑜽

\xn  mv nai hav kau tu tam dai ne ban au vi

\lx  𑜃𑜦𑜧𑜉𑜣𑜉𑜂𑜫

\xe  𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜦𑜧𑜉𑜣𑜉𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜥 𑜍𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜣𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽

\gn  ၸိုဝ်ႈ တင်း ၼေမိမင်း ၸူး ႁၢၼ်ႉ ၼိၵ်ႈပၢၼ်ႇ မိူင်း ႁူင် ။

\xe  𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜒𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜣 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜁𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜉𑜀𑜫 𑜽

\xn  khau chang pin tang sin nai on nang ting ko si to ban nai khen mak
\xr  'Then silk skirts are made for the ladies to wear, and up to this day we are richer.'
\xv

\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\lx  𑜃𑜧𑜧
\lxx  n]]
\ph  nav nav
\ps  express
\ge  EXPRESS-side to side
\de  expressive meaning 'side to side'
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၼၢဝ်းၼၢဝ်း
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 13v5
\xe  𑜃𑜧𑜧 𑜁𑜧𑜪 𑜆𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜥 𑜽
\xex  n]] x]M puNq niuw rU /
\xn  nav nav khem paai nv ru
\xr  'Moving side to side, a reed adorns his head.'
\xv 
\gn  ၼၢဝ်းၼၢဝ်း ၶႅမ် ပူၺ်ႈ ၼိူဝ် ႁူဝ် ။

\lx  𑜃𑜪 𑜏𑜥 𑜎𑜡
\lxx  nM sU la
\ph  nam su la
\ps  n.
\ge  alcohol
\de  alcohol
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 59r-7
\dn  𑜉𑜦𑜡 𑜕𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  ema eKa rokq
\dr  mo go rok
\dv  মগৰক
\gr  মগৰক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Probably Assamese modh. Nabin Shyam suggested that this meant 'Buddhist holy recitals'. The word mOgOr is Hindi word for 'crocodile'. Chaichuen suggested that nam su la should mean 'alcohol' from Pali-Sanskrit sura 'intoxicating liquor'
\dt  06/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  nE[q
\ph  nvng
\hm  1
\ps  v.

\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 24r-10
\dn  𑜏𑜦𑜧 𑜒𑜠 𑜓𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  es] A; dI borq
\dr  se a di bor
\dv  --- দিবৰ
\gr  --- দিবৰ
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B116
\xe  𑜃𑜪 𑜋𑜥 𑜃𑜪 𑜁𑜠 𑜃𑜪 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜠 𑜃𑜪𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 ...
\xex  nM cU nM x; nM fE[q nM nE[q x; nMvE[q ...
\xn  nam chu nam kha nam phvng nam nvng kha nam thvng ...
\xr  'milk, 'kha' water, honey, galangale tea, curd ...'

 (1992) it was given as 'kha tea'.

\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; 12r8
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜩𑜤 𑜽
\xex  h] mnq nnq ninq siNq xunq sju /
\xn  hav man nan nin sen khun saai
\xr  'And make there to be 100,000 princes down on the earth and sandy ground.'

\lx  𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫
\lxx  nEw
\ph  nv
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\sn  1
\ge  up
\de  up
\so

\gr 
\gv  ၼိူဝ်

\xex  tU fU c[q tkq minq mEw nonq konq niuw /
\xn  tu phu chang tak min mv non kon nv
\xr  'The male ones will then fly up and sleep on the upper roost.'

\xv 
\gn  ပၼ် ၶၢပ်ႇ သႅင် ၽႃ ၸႃး ။
\notes 
\dt  16/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜋𑜣
\lxx  cI
\ph  chi
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  paper
\de  paper
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 4v-6
\dn  𑜀𑜠 𑜀𑜦𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜆𑜄𑜫
\dnx  k; ekotq ptq
\dr  ka kot pat
\dv  কাকতপাত
\gr  কাকতপাত
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B91
\xe  𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜎𑜩 𑜎𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜲 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜼
\xex  cw sI lj ela c[q [Enq 2 tokq a
\xn  chau chi lai ko chang ngvn song tok
\xr  'For the scribes a weight of 2 toks of silver'
\xv 
\notes  In the example, the compound <chau chi lai> 'scribe' is literally 'respected paper pattern/writing'

\xe  𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜒𑜃 𑜈𑜧 𑜈𑜠 𑜋𑜥 𑜈𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜄𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜂𑜠 𑜽
\xex  poj An b] b; cU eboa t] nM siNq [; /
\xn  poi an bav ba chu bo tav nam sen nga 
\xr  'And so come in the name of Mo Tav Nam, with the many tusks.'
\xv 
\gn  ပွႆး ဢၼ် မႂ်း မႃး ၸိုဝ်ႈ မေႃ တႂ်ႈ ၼမ်ႉ သႅၼ် ငႃး ။
\notes  This is an alternative spelling for chv.
\dt  22/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜋𑜥
\lxx  cU
\ph  chu
\hm  8
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  reach
\de  reach, to 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r7
\xe  𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜠 𑜋𑜄𑜫 𑜈𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜡 𑜋𑜥 𑜽
\xex  eta k; ctq bi[q c[q ma cU /

\xv 
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  arrive
\de  to arrive
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸူး
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 5r4
\xe  𑜁𑜧 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜎𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜋𑜪 𑜁𑜧 𑜑𑜧 𑜉𑜣 𑜋𑜥 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  x] c[q poj lu[q m; xo] cM x] h] mI cU knq fo[q /
\xn  khav chang poi lung ma khau cham khav hav mi chu kan phong 
\xr  'And then they came down and arrived and wanted to have control.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶဝ် ၸင်ႇ ပွႆး လူင်း မႃး ၶဝ် ၸမ်း ၶႂ်ႈ ႁႂ်ႈ မီး ၸူး ၵၼ် ၽွင်း ။

\de  to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸူး

\xex  si[qu no]w tkq ba cU n[q xI s[q efoa poj munq /
\xn  seng nau tak ba chu nang khi sang pho poi mun 
\xr  'The diamond star will say to the lady to ride on a ship, and it will be enjoyable.'
\xv 
\gn  သႅင် လၢဝ် တၵ်း ဝႃႈ ၸူး ၼၢင်း ၶီႇ သၢင်းၽေႃး ပွႆး မူၼ်ႈ ။
\notes  The phrase <ma chu> 'come reach' is a completive. The whole line is literally 'approaching the surrounding elephants and coming to
 reach them.'

\xn  han tang jvng cham pha but rum lav lav

\gn  ႁၼ် တင်း ယိူင်း ၸမ်ႈ ၾႃႉ မူတ်း ႁူမ်ႇ (ႁူမ်ႈ) လႂ်လႂ် ။

\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B12
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜡 𑜈𑜩𑜎𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜲 𑜀𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜲 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜍𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  h] t[q ema bjlu[q 2 kunq [Enq c[q 2 pkq xM c[q sI ro[q a
\xn  hav tang mo bai lung 2 kun ngvn chang song pak kham chang si rong
\xr  'Two Bai Lo'ng priests (Seng Mvng priests) will receive two hundred [pieces of] silver and gold weighing four ro'ng,'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  07/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜋𑜂𑜫
\lxx  c[q
\ph  chang
\hm  9
\ps  v.
\ge  stand.still
\de  to stand still; to be firm, fixed
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸင်ႈ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 18v7
\xe  𑜲 𑜁𑜩𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  2 xjfa eka c[q pinq kiw pinq nonq c[q mnq /
\xn  song khai pha ko chang pin kiu pin non chang man 
\xr  'The two kings will then be chewing and sleeping still.'
\xv 
\gn  သွင် ၶႆႇၾႃႉ ၵေႃႈ ၸင်ႇ ပဵၼ် ၵဵဝ်ႉ ပဵၼ် ၼွၼ်း ၸင်ႈ မၼ်ႈ ။

\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B16
\xe  𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  n]w tnq knq cM n]w cikq co[q a
\xn  nau tan kan cham nau chik chong
\xr  'When it comes in line with the Tip of the Umbrella Stars'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤
\sex  co[qu

\lx  𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫
\lxx  co[q
\ph  chong
\hm  9
\ps  v.
\ge  pull
\de  pull, to; draw, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B172
\xe  𑜇𑜧 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜋𑜪 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜣 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜼
\xex  f] s[q poj bw su[q sI hnq xinq mE[q co[q n[q nj cM bw nI koj a
\xn  phav sang poi bau sung si han khin mvng chong nang nai cham bau ni koi
\xr  'But if he does not act in this way when danger threatens the country, it will not be good'
\xv 
\notes  In the example, the phrase <khin mvng chong nang nai> is literally 'when danger pulls the country like this>. The word <han> is of
 uncertain meaning.

\xn  mo lik tang phi rang mo khang tang phi chan
\xr  '(It is in) an iron pot is given to the spirits of the house; in a metal pot is given to those spirits who know everything.'

\lx  𑜋𑜰𑜫
\lxx  cw
\ph  chau
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  morning
\de  morning 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸဝ်ႉ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 1v1
\xe  𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜆𑜩 𑜍𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜉𑜠 𑜆𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  lukq cw h] pj rikq t[q ema s[q fa m; po[q /
\xn  luk chau hav pai rik tang mo sang pha ma pong
\xr  'When he woke in the morning, he made someone go and call the Mo Sang Pha to come and take care of this.'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜋𑜧𑜨
\sex  co]
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸဝ်ႉ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 5r6

\xex  pi[q eta fj lM mj n] co] /
\xn  ping to phai lam mai nau chau
\xr  'Upright like the tree trunks in the (stillness) of early morning.'
\xv 
\gn  ပႅင် တေႃႈ ၽၢႆႉ လမ်း မႆႉ ၼႂ် ၸဝ်ႉ ။

\sex  co]w
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸဝ်ႉ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 11v1
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜟𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜧𑜨 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜃𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜂𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜟𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜽
\xex  h] n[q lukq co]w n[q <[q xunq eka bw to] si[qu no]w tnq xoM e[a sE[q e<a et] /
\xn  hav nang luk chau nang khrang khun ko bau tau seng nau tan khom ngo svng khro te 
\xr  'He had got the lady to get up in the morning and sit side by side with the prince, but she did not arrive and the diamond star spoke
 words wrinkled with hidden meaning.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁႂ်ႈ ၼၢင်း လုၵ်ႉ ၸဝ်ႉ ၼင်ႈ ၶၢင်း ၶုၼ် ၵေႃႈ မဝ်ႇ တဝ်ႈ သႅင် လၢဝ် တၢၼ်ႈ ၵႂၢမ်ႈ ငေႃး သိူင်ႇ ၶေႃႈ တႄႉ ။

\dt  20/Jul/2011

\dr  o di ka rok
\dv  অধিকাৰক
\gr  অধিকাৰক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  In the first example <bau chau phan> is literally 'NEG be type', translated are 'are not (ordinary) type.'
\dt  20/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜋𑜧𑜨
\lxx  co]
\ph  chau
\hm  11
\ps  prep.
\ge  to
\de  to; arrive, to 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4r3
\xe  𑜃𑜧 𑜏𑜩 𑜁𑜧 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜧𑜨 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜍𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜁𑜩 𑜽
\xex  n] sj x] c[q to] co] r[q m; xj /
\xn  nav sai khau chang tau chau rang ma khai
\xr  'In the late morning they arrive at the nest to lay eggs.'
\xv 
\notes  The word <chau> is probably a variant of <chu> and <su>, a grammaticalisation of a verb meaning something like 'arrive'
\dt  20/Jul/2011

\dr  av u ko
\dv  এওঁক
\gr  এওঁক

\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 10v1
\xe  𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜪 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜽

\xv

\notes  There are two possible meanings for the Assames /ou/ 'term of address for person of inferior rank', or 'type of citrus fruit'. This
 word is perhaps related to /chau/.

\lx  𑜋𑜩𑜨
\lxx  coj
\ph  choi
\hm  6
\ps  n.
\ge  viss
\de  viss, a unit of measurement. According to Sao Tern Moeng's Shan Dictionary, its value is 100 ticals, about 3.3 lbs.
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၸွႆႉ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 18v2
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜪 𑜒𑜪𑜨 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜎𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜡 𑜃𑜡 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜩𑜨 𑜽
\xex  h] t[q k]w mE[q [iukq eka nM AoM niuNq xM lnq xi[q la na mE[q coj /
\xn  hav tang kav mvng ngvk ko nam om nvi kham lan khing la na mvng choi 
\xr  'Make the 90,000 water serpents begin to make millions of water pots with gold, with patterned lines, thick to 10,000 visses.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁႂ်ႈ တင်း ၵဝ်ႈ မိုၼ်ႇ ငိူၵ်ႈ ၵေႃႇ ၼမ်ႉ ဢွမ် (လူၺ်ႈ) ၶမ်း လၢၼ်ႉ (ၶႅင်း) လၢႆး ၼႃ မိုၼ်ႇ ၸွႆႉ ။

\xe  𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜥𑜉𑜣𑜏𑜡 𑜃𑜩 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜥 𑜉𑜢 𑜏𑜡 𑜼
\xex  eka c[q tkq nj t[q xunq tUmIsa nj n[q tU mi sa a
\xn  ko chang tak nai tang khun tumisa nai nang tumisa
\xr  'then were captured the Tumisa king and the Tumisa queen'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  31/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜦𑜧
\lxx  et]
\ph  te
\hm  3
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  establish
\de  to establish
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တႄႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 7v6
\xe  𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜧𑜤 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜈𑜦𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜑𑜦𑜪𑜡 𑜽
\xex  epa kiu[q pinq p]u kw cw ebo[qu et] ehaM /
\xn  po kvng pin pau kau chau bong te ho kham 
\xr  '(The father said), If she is suitable to be a daughter in law for me, the respected emperor who has established a palace.'
\xv 
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  build
\de  build, to 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4v4
\xe  𑜈𑜤𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜇𑜠 𑜒𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜽
\xex  buo[q et] f; A] mEw eha ru[q xMQ hitq cw /
\xn  bong te pha au mvw ho rung kham hit chau
\xr  'Emperor who created the universe (will) take him and go to the palace of the golden throne and make him a king.'
\xv 
\gn  ပေႃး ၵိုင်ႇ ပဵၼ် ပႂ်ႉ ၵဝ် ၸဝ်ႈ ဝူင်ႉ တႄႇ ႁေႃၶမ်း ။
\sn  3
\ge  begin
\de  to begin
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တႄႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 6v2
\xe  𑜊𑜡 𑜈𑜡 𑜆𑜣 𑜇𑜡 𑜋𑜨𑜆𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜃𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜈𑜡 𑜀𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜦𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  ya ba pI fa copq co] n[q si[qu no]w ba kM niw et] en] mEnq y] /
\xn  ja ba pi pha chop chau nang seng nau ba kam niu te ne mvn jav 
\xr  '(The king said) Do not make me, the elder one of the sky, plead with (you) lady. In a minute I will start to show you.'
\xv 
\gn  ယႃႇ ဝႃႈ ပီႈ ၾႃႉ ၸွပ်ႇ ၸႂ် ၼၢင်း သႅင် လၢဝ် ဝႃႈ ၵမ်း လဵဝ် တႄႇ ၼႄ မိူၼ် ယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜦𑜧
\lxx  et]
\ph  te
\hm  5
\ps  adj., part.
\sn  1
\ge  true
\de  true 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တႄႉ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 21r3
\xe  𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜡 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜇𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜩 𑜋𑜪 𑜉𑜧 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜊𑜡 𑜃𑜡 𑜃𑜥 𑜋𑜥 𑜽
\xex  s[q ma lkq fitq et] nj cM m] n[q ya na nU cU /
\xn  sang ma lak phit te nai cham mav nang ya na nu chu
\xr  'Even if you make mistake do not show it on your face.'
\xv 
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  TRUE
\de  particle
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တႄႉ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r5
\xe  𑜃𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜍𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜡 𑜽
\xex  nnq vE[q ninq citq rnq et] na /
\xn  nan thvng nin chit ran te na
\xr  'Truly the noise (of my voice) will reach the seven layers of ground.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  The phrase <te na> is conventionalised as an combination of two particles. <te> is the word 'true' 
\notes  The phrase <phit te nai> in the example is literally 'a true mistake, a real mistake'
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜩
\lxx  tj
\ph  tai
\hm  5
\ps  n.
\ge  side
\de  side
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တၢႆႈ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r3
\xe  𑜄𑜩 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜀𑜥 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜎𑜧 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜩𑜡 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜦𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  tj kw emoa tkq m; kU si[q cM l] cw xja kw ep] mE[q pkq /
\xn  tai kau mo tak ma ku sing cham lau chau khai pha kau pe mvng pak
\xr  'I the learned one will come and speak to my great king who is the support for a hundred countries.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  The word tai appears to mean 'side', but is not translated in the English free translation, it means literally 'my voice, which is the side
 of the learned one, is effective.'
\dt  26/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜩
\lxx  tj
\ph  tai
\hm  7
\ps  v.
\ge  walk.with.torch
\de  walk with a torch, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 5r-23
\dn  𑜊𑜤𑜍𑜫 𑜎𑜦𑜡 𑜕𑜩 𑜇𑜥 𑜍𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫

\dr  jur loi phu ri bor
\dv  জাৰ্ লৈ ফুৰিবৰ
\gr  জাৰ্ লৈ ফুৰিবৰ
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Junaram Phuakn said that /jur lo gai phu ri bor/ might also be said as /ba jur lo gai phu ri bor/ where /ba/ means 'air' so it would mean 'to
 walk in an airy atmosphere' (air touching the body while walking
 leisurely).

\lx  𑜄𑜩 𑜄𑜤𑜆𑜫

\gv  တဝ်ႈ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4v7
\xe  𑜄𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜧 𑜒𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜈𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜧 𑜽
\xex  t] mE[q m] A]w mEw bkq kEnq s] /
\xn  tav mvng mav au mv bak kvn sav
\xr  'He arrives in a new country and go to grab the taxes and stay there.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\hm  13

\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 5v-8
\dn  𑜒𑜥 𑜘𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  AU eBa tI borq
\dr  u bho ti bor
\dv  উভিতবৰ
\gr  উভিতবৰ
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B29
\xe  𑜆𑜣 𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫𑜑𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜥 𑜄𑜧 𑜏𑜣 𑜋𑜪 𑜼
\xex  pI hnq cM cw sEwhu[q tkq lU t] sI cM a
\xn  pi han cham chau sv hung tak lu tav si cham
\xr  'That year King Sva Hung was ruined and died'
\xv 
\notes  In the example 'tav' literally means 'to return (to heaven)' but metaphorically means 'to die'.

\lx  𑜄𑜪
\lxx  tM
\ph  tam
\hm  2
\ps  n., dem.
\sn  1
\ge  there
\de  there
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တမ်ႈ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 9v6
\xe  𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜧𑜂𑜫 𑜊𑜥 𑜄𑜪 𑜀𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜠 𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜩 𑜽
\xex  mnq y][q yU tM ko]w ri[q x; ru[q rj /
\xn  man jang ju tam kau ring kha rung rai 
\xr  'And he still stays there at the nine thousand branches of the banyan and Eugenia trees.'
\xv 
\gn  မၼ်း ယင်း ယူႇ တမ်ႈ ၵဝ်ႈ ႁဵင် ၶႃႈ ႁုင်း ႁႆး ။
\sn  2
\ge  at
\de  at
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တမ်ႈ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 2r4
\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜱 𑜊𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜡𑜀𑜡 𑜀𑜠 𑜏𑜧 𑜍𑜨𑜆𑜫 𑜊𑜥 𑜄𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  pE[q z yinq pinq laka k; s] ropq yU tM niuw mnq koj y] /
\xn  pvng lvng jin pin laka ka sav rop ju tam nv man koi jav 
\xr  'And secondly, he turned into a Naga that rested around above him.'
\xv 
\gn  ပိူင် ၼိုင်ႈ ယဵၼ်း ပဵၼ် (ငူးယၢဝ်းၽွမ်တႃ) ၵႂႃႇ သဝ်း ႁွပ်ႈ ယူႇ တမ်ႈ ၼိူဝ် မၼ်း ၵွႆး ယဝ်ႉ ။
\sn  3
\ge  here
\de  here, there
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 8r7
\xe  𑜇𑜩 𑜒𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜪 𑜇𑜡 𑜽
\xex  fj A]w mi[q xunq mi[q n[q mE[q Aokq tM fa /
\xn  phai au ming khun ming nang mvng ok tam pha
\xr  'Walk and take out the tutelary spirit of the king of the queen of the country from the sky.'
\xv 
\notes  In the example, the phrase <ok tam pha> is literally 'come.out here sky', and is rendered in English without a direct translation of <tam>
\sn  4
\ge  place
\de  place
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တမ်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 14r5
\xe  𑜄𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜪 𑜃𑜪 𑜀𑜆𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  tunq mnq pinq tM nM kpq eta s] mE[q /
\xn  tun man pin tam nam kap to sau mvng 
\xr  'Its source is where the water joins to Mount Meru.'
\xv 
\gn  တူၼ်ႈ မၼ်း ပဵၼ် တမ်ႈ ၼမ်ႉ ၵပ်း တေႃႇ သဝ် မိူင်း ။
\notes 
\dt  27/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜪
\lxx  tM
\ph  tam
\hm  3
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  pound
\de  pound, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 5v-19
\dn  𑜁𑜥 𑜓𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  xU dI borq
\dr  khu di bor
\dv  খুদিবৰ
\gr  খুদিবৰ
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\sn  2
\ge  pound
\de  pound, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 43r-18
\dn  𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜏𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜁𑜥 𑜓𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  eha emosq et] xU dI borq
\dr  ho mos te khu di bor

\gv  တၵ်း
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 16r6
\xe  𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜦𑜧 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜥 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜇𑜡 𑜒𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜥 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜠 𑜽
\xex  kw n[q nonq niuw tkq xunq mE[q h] cEnq en] bnq cw fU pE[q si[qu fa Aonq niuw rU kw n[q h; /

\lx  𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫
\lxx  tokq
\ph  tok
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  measure.of.weight
\de  a measure of weight
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B91
\xe  𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜎𑜩 𑜎𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜲 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜼
\xex  cw sI lj ela c[q [Enq 2 tokq a
\xn  chau chi lai ko chang ngvn song tok
\xr  'For the scribes a weight of 2 toks of silver.'
\xv 
\notes  Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:150) note "a measure of weight; according to Nabin Shyam, the Tai Aiton and Tai Phakey at present
 consider the tok to weigh approximately one kilogram, but in these
 texts the tok is used for amounts of gold we assume it to be a much
 smaller weight.'
\dt  31/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜂𑜫
\lxx  t[q
\ph  tang
\hm  11
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  set.up
\de  to set up
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 20v1
\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜧𑜤 𑜍𑜣 𑜁𑜪 𑜽
\xex  pi[q eta pEnq t[q s]u rI xM /
\xn  ping to pvn tang sau ri kham
\xr  'In the same way, others set up long golden posts.'
\xv 
\gn  ပႅင်တေႃႈ ပိူၼ်ႈ တင်ႈ သဝ် ႁီး ၶမ်း ။
\sn  2
\ge  place
\de  to place; to arrange
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 9v2
\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜦𑜪𑜡 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜩 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜆𑜫 𑜁𑜩 𑜽
\xex  pinq[q xunq mE[q eka em] t[q ehaM t[q lj lkq xipq xj /
\xn  pin nang khun mvng ko me tang ho kham tang lai lak khip khai 
\xr  'Like this, the prince of the country will prepare the palace, set up the pattern (of government), to be the royal egg seated by his side.'
\xv 
\gn  ပဵၼ်ၼင်ႇ ၶုၼ် မိူင်း ၵေႃႈ မႄး တင်း ႁေႃၶမ်း တင်ႈ လၢႆး လၵ်း ၶႅပ်ႇ ၶႆႇ ။
\sn  3
\ge  establish
\de  establish, to; set up, to; place in its proper position, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4
\xe  𑜇𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜝𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜀𑜃𑜣 𑜁𑜪𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜣𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜣𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜈𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜧 𑜼
\xex  fa c[q pRu[q knq lknI xMmE[q pIpnq pIknq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn  pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham nin to tav
\xr  'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down
 to the earth underneath.'
\xv 
\gn 
\sn  4
\ge  upright
\de  to be upright
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 14r6
\xe  𑜉𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜀𑜣 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜨𑜡 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  mu[q hnq ecoa kI n[q t[q rnq foa fEkq hiNq xunq /
\xn  mung han cho ki nang tang ran pha phvk hen khun 
\xr  'Looking and seeing the alchemist sitting upright at the level of the white stones, looking towards the prince.'
\xv 
\gn  မုင်ႈ ႁၼ် ၸေႃႇၵီႇ ၼင်ႈ တင်ႈ ႁၢၼ်ႉ ၽႃ ၽိူၵ်ႇ ႁႅၼ် ၶုၼ် ။
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\ps  adj.
\ge  all

\dnx  eha eka ela kU

\dv  সকলোকো
\gr  সকলোকো
\gv  တင်း
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 9r1
\xe  𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜁 𑜍𑜠 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜌𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜊𑜀𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽

\lx  𑜄𑜂𑜫
\lxx  t[q
\ph  tang
\hm  15
\ps  part.
\ge  with
\de  with 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တင်း
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r7
\xe  𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜠 𑜈𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜣 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜥 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜦 𑜃𑜡 𑜽
\xex  hnq t[q fu[q c[q t; bi[q mE[q tI cw sU xunq mE[q kw et na /
\xn  han tang phung chang ta bing mvng ti chau su khun mvng kau te na
\xr  'See a group of elephants, surrounding the country of the Lord, king of the land, oh me!'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  The word <tang> is regularly found preceding animate non-agent arguments in Ahom. The example here, <han tang phung chang>
 'see with group elephant' is translated into English as simply 'See a
 group of elephants'
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜂𑜫

\ph  tang
\hm  6
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  donate
\de  donate, to; present, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တၢင်ႇ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 6v7
\xe  𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜣 𑜍𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜣 𑜋𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  emoa likq t[q fI r[q emoa x[q t[q fI cnq /

\sn  2
\ge  present
\de  to present

\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တၢင်ႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 3v3
\xe  𑜑𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜩 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  hunq siNq k; em] t[q rj si[q /
\xn  hun sen ka me tang rai sing
\xr  'The one whose form is valued at 100,000 (the king) will reform the system of the tribute.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁုၼ်ႇ သႅၼ် ၵႃႈ မႄး တၢင်ႇ ႁၢႆး သႅင် ။

\lx  𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜠
\lxx  t[q k;
\ph  tang ka
\ps  conj.
\ge  all
\de  all
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တင်းၵႃႈ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r4
\xe  𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜊𑜥 𑜃𑜪𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜥 𑜽
\xex  t[q k; [iukq yU nMQ [inq kU /
\xn  tang ka ngvk ju nam ngin ku
\xr  'Even all the sea monsters living in the water are afraid (of the great king).'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜃𑜫
\lxx  t[q rnq
\ph  tang ran
\ps  n.
\ge  ?
\de  ?
\so  Loti Amra; (Prem Phukon); 8v-3
\dn  𑜈𑜣 𑜔𑜠 𑜓𑜣 𑜒𑜠 𑜆𑜡 𑜄𑜨𑜄𑜫
\dnx  bI D; dI A; pa totq
\dr  bindha dia patot
\dv  বিন্ধা দিয়া পাতত
\gr  বিন্ধা দিয়া পাতত
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Junaram Phukan said another meaning of /pat/ is 'akon' seat and /bi dhan/ means 'custom'. So the whole might mean 'the act of taking a
 seat in religious prayer by a person, throne (by king), or placing
 things on a plate according to custom'. In Shan /taang/ means 'place
 upon'.
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜢𑜂𑜫
\lxx  ti[q
\ph  ting
\hm  9
\ps  v.

\gn  ပေႃး ဢၼ် လုမ်ႈ ဝၼ်း တုင်း ပၼ်ႇ ၶွပ်ႈ ။

\xv

\lx  𑜄𑜨𑜂𑜫
\lxx  to[q
\ph  tong
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  stomach
\de  stomach, belly
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 25v-3
\dn  𑜆𑜦𑜧 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  ep] tokq
\dr  pe tok
\dv  পেটক
\gr  পেটক
\gv  တွင်ႉ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 2v1
\xe  𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜣 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  bnq nI cw c[q Aokq to[q em] pinq kunq /
\xn  ban ni chau chang ok tong me pin kun
\xr  'On this good day, then, he would then come out of the stomach of the mother and became a person.'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜄𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤
\sex  to[qu
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တွင်ႉ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 2v5
\xe  𑜇𑜣 𑜊𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜟𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜄𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  fI y[q ?nq h] cw kw xo] to[qu em] bnq hu[q /
\xn  phi jang phran hav chau kau khau tong me ban hung 
\xr  '(The lady said) (Then) the spirit made my Lord enter the womb of his mother on the famous day.'
\xv 
\gn  ၽီ ယင်း ၽၢၼ်ႇ ႁႂ်ႈ ၸဝ်ႈ ၵဝ် ၶဝ်ႈ တွင်ႉ မႄႈ ဝၼ်း ႁူင် ။

\xv 
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜃𑜫
\lxx  tnq
\ph  tan
\hm  7
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  be.in.line
\de  be in line, to; extend, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B14
\xe  𑜄𑜂𑜫𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜋𑜪 𑜃𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜡𑜀𑜡 𑜼
\xex  t[qAnq n]w xMmE[q tnq knq nj cM n]w laka a
\xn  tang an nau kham mvng tan kan nai cham nau la ka
\xr  'When it occurs that Kham Mvng comes in line with the Naga stars'
\xv  যেতিয়া এইটো হয় তেতিয়া খাম মুং নগা তাৰকাপুঞ্জৰ সৈতে একে শাৰীত থাকে ।
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  go.straight
\de  to go straight
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တၢၼ်း
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 13v1
\xe  𑜁𑜩𑜈𑜡 𑜄𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜎𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜃𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜽
\xex  xjba tnq pju linq vEnq fa nu[q hoM /
\xn  khai pha tan paai lin thvn pha nung hom 
\xr  'The king went straight to enjoy the far and fragrant forest.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶႆႇၾႃႉ တၢၼ်း ပႆ လဵၼ်ႈ ထိူၼ်ႇ ၾႃႉ လူင် ႁွမ် ။
\notes  This word is found in Tai Mao in the meaning 'go straight'
\notes 
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\dt  28/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜄𑜃𑜫
\lxx  tnq
\ph  tan
\hm  9
\ps  adj.
\ge  speechless
\de  speechless
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 34r-5
\dn  𑜃𑜣 𑜉𑜠 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  nI m; tokq
\dr  ni ma tok
\dv  নিমাতক
\gr  নিমাতক
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  The Assamese term nimatok certainly means 'speechless', but that is an unlikely meaning for tan given that the usual meaning of tan is 'to speak.'
\dt  28/Aug/2011

\xe  𑜇𑜦𑜧 𑜏𑜣 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫𑜇𑜩 𑜏𑜣 𑜄𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜄𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜼
\xex  ef] sI fEnq ema to[q sI lukq lukq likq sI lukq lukq likqfj sI tonq likq x[q sI tonq a

\xr  'four large plates, four copper pots, four iron flints, four pieces of alloy'

\ps  onom

\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  တွမ်ႇ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 7r7
\xe  𑜉𑜢 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜨𑜆𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜪𑜨 𑜉𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜧 𑜽

\xr  'And (I) have a drum that sounds top tom which I will give you.'

\lx  𑜆𑜡
\lxx  pa
\ph  pa
\hm  10
\ps  v.
\ge  lead
\de  to lead
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႃး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 13r3
\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜨𑜡 𑜄𑜥 𑜎𑜢𑜤𑜉𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜁𑜟𑜧 𑜏𑜣 𑜍𑜥 𑜉𑜣 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜄𑜥 𑜃𑜧𑜤 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜆𑜡 𑜀𑜤𑜆𑜫 𑜀𑜥 𑜉𑜣 𑜈𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜟𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  pEnq boa tU lEmq mEw eka <] sI rU mI co] tU nu] eka pa kupq kU mI bw ?kq koj y] /
\xn  pvn ba tu lvm mv ko khrav si ru mi chau tu nav ko pa kup ku mi bau phrak koi jau 
\xr  'Others say it is pythons going and wanting to rub their heads against the partner's body, which bodies are leading in pairs and are
 not separated.'
\xv 
\gn  ပိူၼ်ႈ ဝႃႈ တူဝ် လိူမ် မိူဝ်း ၵေႃႈ ၶႂ်ႈ သီ ႁူဝ် မီး ၸဝ်ႈ တူဝ် လႂ် ၵေႃႈ ပႃး ၵူပ်ႉ ၵူႈ မီး မဝ်ႇ ၾၢၵ်ႈ ၵွႆး ယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  19/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜆𑜡
\lxx  pa
\ph  pa
\hm  11
\ps  part.
\ge  PROH
\de  prohibitive marker, do not
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv 
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 13v5
\xe  𑜁𑜪 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜧 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜠 𑜆𑜡 𑜑𑜩 𑜽
\xex  xM s[q m] xunq y; pa hj /
\xn  kham sang mav khun ya pa hai
\xr  '"Any way, you prince, do not cry."' 
\xv 
\gn

\lx  𑜆𑜡𑜃𑜡𑜏𑜣
\lxx  panasI
\ph  pa na si
\ps  n.

\de  Varanasi, ancient city of India
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႃႇၼႃႇသီႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 2v2
\xe  𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜈𑜡 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜑𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜦𑜧 𑜇𑜩𑜡 𑜆𑜡𑜃𑜡𑜏𑜣 𑜃𑜣 𑜄𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  eta ba piunq eka hu[q t[q ec] fja panasI nI tonq et y] /
\xn  to ba pvn ko hung tang che phai pha pa na si ni ton te jau 
\xr  'Yet others spread the fame of the land of Varanasi, (a place) good and celebrated.'
\xv 
\gn  တေႃႈ ဝႃႈ ပိူၼ်ႈ ၵေႃႈ ႁူင် တင်း ၸႄႈ ၽၢႆႇၾႃႉ ပႃႇၼႃႇသီႇ လီ တွၼ်း တႄႉယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  20/Jul/2011

\dn  𑜉𑜠 𑜍𑜦𑜡 𑜎𑜢𑜀𑜫
\dnx  m; era likq
\dr  ma ro lik
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r3
\xe  𑜄𑜩 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜨𑜡 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜀𑜥 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜎𑜧 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜩𑜡 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜦𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  tj kw emoa tkq m; kU si[q cM l] cw xja kw ep] mE[q pkq /

\lx  𑜆𑜩
\lxx  pj
\ph  pai
\hm  13
\ps  adv.
\ge  yet
\de  yet; not yet
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႆႇ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 1r1
\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜊𑜪𑜣 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜧 𑜇𑜡 𑜆𑜩 𑜉𑜣 𑜓𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  pinq n[q yMI mEw rnq eka t] fa pj mI dinq /
\xn  pin nang jem mv ran ko tav pha pai mi din 
\xr  'Like this, at that time there was not yet any ground under the sky.'
\xv 
\gn  ပဵၼ် ၼင်ႇ ယၢမ်း မိူဝ်ႈ ႁၼ်ႉ ၵေႃႈ တႂ်ႈ ၽႃႉ ပႆႇ မီး လိၼ် ။
\se  𑜆𑜩𑜤
\sex  pju
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႆႇ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 13v7
\xe  𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜉𑜣 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜣 𑜆𑜥 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜩𑜨 𑜊𑜧 𑜽
\xex  pju mI n[q nI pU sEw xM xunq nonq koj y] /
\xn  pai mi nang ni pu sv kham khun non koi jav 
\xr  'He does not yet have a queen to spread a golden mat for the prince to sleep.'
\xv 
\gn  ပႆႇ မီး ၼၢင်း လီ ပူ သိူဝ်ႇ ၶမ်း ၶုၼ် ၼွၼ်း ၵွႆး ယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜆𑜩
\lxx  pj
\ph  pai, paai
\hm  5
\ps  v.
\ge  go
\de  go, to; move, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 6r-17
\dn  𑜊𑜠 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  y; borq
\dr  ja bor
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႆ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 5v9
\xe  𑜁𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜧 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜥 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩 𑜊𑜥 𑜄𑜪𑜫 𑜽
\xex  xonq m] cw sU xunq mE[q pj yU tMQ /
\xn  khon mav chau su khun mvng pai ju tam
\xr  'You spirit, of the tiger prince of the country, go and live there!'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜆𑜩𑜤
\sex  pju
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပႆ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 8r5
\xe  𑜉𑜧 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜎𑜦 𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜇𑜩𑜤 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜍𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜣 𑜃𑜩𑜨 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜏𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  m] poj el pju fju xnq pnq m; rotq kow tI noj x[q fa s] mE[q /
\xn  mav poi le pai phaai khan pan ma rot kau ti noi khang pha sav mvng 
\xr  'And you will roam twirling quickly, arriving back to me at the metal hill of the sky, which is the post of the country.'
\xv 
\gn  မႂ်း ပွႆး လႄႇ ပႆ ၽၢႆႈ ၶၼ် ပၼ်ႇ မႃး ႁွတ်ႈ ၵဝ် တီႈ လွႆ ၶၢင် ၾႃႉ သဝ် မိူင်း ။
\notes  In this example, <pai> has the sense of movement. In fact the spirit is being invited to return to the country, so no sense of movement
 away is implied.
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜆𑜩

\gn  ၶမ်း လႅင် ငိၼ်းၽၢၼ် တၢၼ်ႈ ၵႂၢမ်း မိူဝ်း သူ ပၢႆႈ တႄႉယဝ်ႉ ။

\lx  𑜆𑜩
\lxx  pj
\ph  pai
\hm  9

\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပၢႆႈ
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B83
\xe  𑜆𑜩 𑜇𑜡 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜥 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜒𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜡 𑜍𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜱 𑜼
\xex  pj fa nEw rU eka A] t[q fa fEkq hia r[q eka z a
\xn  pai pha nv ru ko av tang pha phvk hit rang ko 1
\xr  'worship the gods above [our] heads by taking white cloth and making a figure'
\xv 
\gn

\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xex  si[qu no]wu fEw mEw xEnq ehaM pj epa /
\xn  seng nau phv mv khvn ho kham pai po

\dn  𑜆𑜧 𑜒𑜥 𑜆𑜣 𑜔𑜡 𑜍𑜣 𑜀𑜠
\dnx  p] AU pI Da rI k;
\dr  pav u pi dha ri ka
\dv 
\gr 
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Junaram Phukan suggests /pav/ means 'air' and /dha r ka/ could be 'a belt tied with japi, to hold the japi'

\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 14v7
\xe  𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜪𑜨 𑜎𑜪𑜤 𑜉𑜞𑜠 𑜍𑜠 𑜉𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜏𑜡 𑜃𑜥 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜣 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜥 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜁𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜟𑜠 𑜽
\xex  mnq y[q s[q cnq mokq poM luM Sm; r; mitq sa nU eka xi[q xunq xI t[q bU si[qu x]w <; /
\xn  man jang sang chan mok pom lum mra ra mit sa nu ko khing khun khi tang bu seng khau khra 
\xr  'He orders that the clouds high up be pulled in .... looking at the prince riding a diamond ox with two branches horns.'
\xv 
\gn  မၼ်း ယင်း သင်ႇ ၸၼ် မွၵ်ႇ ပွမ် လူမ်း မႃး (မြႃး?) (ႁႃး) (မိတ်း) (သႃ) လူ ၵေႃႈ ၶိင်း ၶုၼ် ၶီႇ တင်း ဝူဝ်း သႅင် ၶဝ် ၶႃႈ ။
\notes 
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\xr  'I the learned man will say to the great king'.

\xr  'With the magic medicine and the golden creeper, he considers that it will not grow in the midst of the country above the stone.'
\xv 
\gn  ယႃႈ ပူးလွၵ်ႇ ၶိူဝ်း ၶမ်း ၸမ်း (ယဵဝ်) မဝ်ႇ ၽုၵ်ႇ ၵၢင် မိူင်း ၼိူဝ် ၽႃ ။

 meaning 'to plant a sapling'

\lx  𑜆𑜂𑜫
\lxx  p[q
\ph  pang
\hm  9
\ps  n.
\ge  satin
\de  satin, this meaning is conjectural according to Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:154)
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B126
\xe  𑜑𑜪𑜤 𑜆𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜪𑜤 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜲 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜆𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜲 ...
\xex  huM p[q huM bnq xM 2 fEnq xpq fa 2 ...
\xn  hum pang hum ban kham song phvn khap pha song ...
\xr  'satin, a piece of cloth with gold silk threads inserted, two pieces of violet cloth ...'
\xv 
\notes  Terwiel and Ranoo suggest that this might be a Chinese loanword. Given the context of the example, it should relate to cloth.
\dt  11/Aug/2011

\xr  'His love (for her) hot, sighed for a long time, at the highest peak.'

\gn  ႁၵ်ႉ ႁွၼ်ႉ ထူၺ်ႈ ၸႂ် ယိုၼ်း ၸွမ် ပိင်း ။
\notes 
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜆𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  pu[q
\ph  pung
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  portion
\de  portion
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 5v5
\xe  𑜉𑜣 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜩 𑜁𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜪 𑜁𑜪 𑜁𑜦𑜡 𑜆𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  mI t[q sj exa cM xM exa pu[q /
\xn  mi tang sai kho cham kham kho pung
\xr  'With a golden necklace hanging down on their necks.'
\xv 
\notes  The meaning of pung as 'portion' was in the Ahom Lexicons. It fits with the context in the example given, where kho pung would mean
 'neck portion'

\lx  𑜆𑜨𑜂𑜫
\lxx  po[q
\ph  pong
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  joint
\de  joint
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပွင်ႈ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 13v7
\xe  𑜈𑜥 𑜋𑜪𑜤 𑜃𑜩 𑜄𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  bU cuM nj tikq so[q po[q bnq tunq /
\xn  bu chum nai tik song pong ban tun
\xr  'Lotus, joyful at the dew, breaking into two joints and twists around.'
\xv

\gv  ပိုင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 16r6
\xe  𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜦𑜧 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜇𑜥 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜇𑜡 𑜒𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜍𑜥 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜠 𑜽
\xex  kw n[q nonq niuw tkq xunq mE[q h] cEnq en] bnq cw fU pE[q si[qu fa Aonq niuw rU kw n[q h; /
\xn  kau nang non nv tak khun mvng hav chvn ne ban chau phu pvng seng pha on nv ru kau nang vi 
\xr  'I the lady will sleep on the lap of the prince of the country, glad that the Lord, the person that I rely on, is the diamond sky, soft above
 my head, Oh!'
\xv 
\gn  ၵဝ် ၼၢင်း ၼွၼ်း ၼိူဝ် တၵ်း ၶုၼ် မိူင်း ႁႂ်ႈ ၸိုၼ်ႈ လႄႈဝၼ်း ၸဝ်ႈ ၽူႈ ပိုင်ႈ သႅင် ၾႃႉ ဢွၼ်ႇ ၼိူဝ် ႁူဝ် ၵဝ် ၼၢင်း ဢိူၺ်း ။
\notes 
\dt  22/Jul/2011

\xr  'The lady did nothing wrong, she did not abandon the teaching (of the Lord) ... bringing his words to an end.'
\xv

\xe  𑜊𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜥 𑜁𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫𑜫  𑜽

\dt  11/Aug/2011

\xe  𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜊𑜒 𑜑𑜪𑜤 𑜉𑜝𑜡 𑜍𑜠 𑜍𑜣 𑜄𑜡𑜠 𑜀𑜠 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜽
\xex  cEw t[q piNq yA huM mRa r; rI ta; k; siNq co] /
\xn  chv tang pen ja hum mra ra ri ta ka sen chau 
\xr  'Her name is Pingya, the wise one, she of the gem like quality, my beautiful one.'
\xv 
\gn  ၸိုဝ်ႈ တင်း ပိၼ်ႇယႃႇ ႁူမ်ႈ မြႃႉရႃရီတႃၵႃ သႅၼ်ႈ ၸဝ်ႈ ။
\notes 
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\gr

\xe  𑜒𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜩𑜨 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜑𑜥 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜥 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜄𑜫𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜄𑜫𑜃𑜩𑜨 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜩 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜠𑜀𑜦𑜧 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜃𑜤𑜀𑜫𑜄𑜥 𑜃𑜦𑜧 𑜼
\xex  A] t[q xoj fEkq hU fEkq mU fEkq pitqhnq fEkq pitqnoj fEkq kj fEkq k;ek] fEkq nukqtU en] a
\xn  av tang khwai phvk hu phvk mu phvk pit han phvk pit noi phvk kai phvk ka ke phvk nuk tu ne
\xr  'offer a white buffalo, a white cow, a white pig, a white goose, a white duck, a white chicken, a white pigeon and a dove'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\xr  'The Red Golden one then floated down on the way to earth below to the country of the golden stone, and coming down side by side, to

\lx  𑜆𑜩𑜨

\ph  poi

\ps  conj.
\ge  if

\dr

\gr 
\gv  ပွႆး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 11v6
\xe  𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜟𑜦𑜡 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜃𑜧 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜽
\xex  cw poj sE[q e<a xoM n] co] /
\xn  chau poi svng khro khom nau chau

\lx  𑜆𑜩𑜨
\lxx  poj
\ph  poi
\hm  7
\ps  part.
\ge  BUT
\de  but, then, a particular with adversative sense
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ပွႆး
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 3r3
\xe  𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜄𑜧𑜨 𑜎𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩𑜨𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜠 𑜎𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜠 𑜽
\xex  xo] poj to] lu[q nojNq c[q pnq [iu[q pnq [; lu[q f; /
\xn  khau poi tau lung noi nyav chang pan ngvng pan nga lung pha
\xr  'They will then come down to the big hill and go around and around coming down from the sky.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes  In examples like this, the effect of the word <poi> is to convey future time.
\dt  17/Aug/2011

\xr  'Thus (she would be) the celebrated and good lady, of more value than a 100,000 pieces under the universe, oh you!'
\xv

 ngin>

\lx  𑜓𑜩𑜨𑜐𑜫
\lxx  dojNq
\ph  doi
\ps 
\ge  mountain
\de 
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  လွႆ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 5v3
\xe  𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜃𑜫 𑜓𑜩𑜨𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜽
\xex  kw tkq mi[q pnq dojNq cM /
\xn  kau tak ming pan doi cham
\xr  'I will make the mountains.'
\xv 
\gn  ၵဝ် တၵ်း မႅင်ႇ ပၼ် လွႆယႂ်ႇ ၸမ်း ။
\notes 
\dt  23/Jul/2011

\lx  𑜉𑜠
\lxx  m;
\ph  ma
\hm  1
\ps  n.
\ge  horse
\de  horse
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃႉ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 2v2
\xe  𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜋𑜪 𑜎𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜽
\xex  Anq n[q pEkq konq xM cM lokq pinq m; /
\xn  an nang pvk kon kham cham lok pin ma
\xr  'Like this, the shell of the golden lump (the prince) transformed into a horse.' 
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜉𑜡
\sex  ma
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 6v-24
\dn  𑜗𑜥 𑜍𑜀𑜫
\dnx  GU rkq
\dr  ghu rak
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃႉ
\rf  Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 2v2
\xe  𑜉𑜡 𑜎𑜪𑜤 𑜉𑜣𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  ma luM mInq pinq pikq /
\xn  ma lum men pin pik
\xr  'A flying horse with wings.'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜉𑜡𑜠
\sex  ma;
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃႉ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 7v1

\xex  ciw si[q t[q l[q ma; /
\xn  chiu sing tang lang ma
\xr  'And a diamond saddle for the back of the horse.'
\xv 
\gn  ၸဵဝ်း သႅင် တင်း လင် မႃႉ ။

\lx  𑜉𑜠
\lxx  m;
\ph  ma
\hm  4
\ps  v.
\ge  come
\de  come, to
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 6v-25
\dn  𑜒𑜠 𑜑𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫
\dnx  A; hI borq
\dr  a hi bor
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃး
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A6
\xe  𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜆𑜣 𑜎𑜀𑜫 𑜃𑜣 𑜁𑜪 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜋𑜪 𑜀𑜥 𑜆𑜣 𑜉𑜠 𑜀𑜥 𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  em] pI lkq nI xM mE[q nj cM kU pI m; kU co[q a
\xn  me pi lak ni kham mvng nai cham ku pi ma ku chong
\xr  'The major time-reckoning systems, Lakni and Kham Mvng, come and revolve every year'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜉𑜡
\sex  ma
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃး
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 8r2
\xe  𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜡 𑜀𑜥 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  siNq xunq su[q suNq c[q kEnq ma kU niunq /
\xn  sen khun sung sui chang kvn ma ku nvn
\xr  'The taxes and elephant tribute are sent by many princes and come every month.'
\xv 
\gn 
\se  𑜉𑜡𑜠
\sex  ma;
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 3v1
\xe  𑜄𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜡𑜠 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜣 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜡 𑜽
\xex  tEnq lEnq ma; vE[q pI niunq mEw niunq ha /
\xn  tvn lvn ma thvng pi nvn mv nvn ha 
\xr  'After that, it reached the fifth month.'
\xv 
\gn  တိုၼ်းလိုၼ်း မႃး ထိုင် ပီ လိူၼ် မိူဝ်ႈ လိူၼ် ႁႃႈ ။
\sn  2
\ge  COME
\de  grammaticalisation of the verb 'come;'
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႃး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 11v4
\xe  𑜁𑜟𑜠 𑜉𑜠 𑜏𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜩𑜈𑜡 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜽
\xex  <; m; sonq eta n[q xjba eka /
\xn  khra ma son to nang khai pha ko
\xr  'He searched in his mind, think over and over about his lady.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁႃ မႃး သွၼ်ႇ တေႃႇ ၼၢင်း ၶႆႇၾႃႉ ၵေႃႈ ။
\notes 
\dt  03/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜉𑜠 𑜃𑜥 𑜍𑜠
\lxx  m; nU r;
\ph  ma nu ra
\ps  adj., v.
\ge  charming
\de  charming; to charm
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မၼုႁႃႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 13v5
\xe  𑜁𑜩𑜈𑜡 𑜑𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜃𑜥 𑜍𑜠 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  xjba hitq linq vEnq m; nU r; n[q mE[q /
\xn  khai pha hit lin thvn ma nu ra nang mvng 
\xr  'The king made himself like a monitor lizard of the forest, for charming the lady of the country.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶႆႇၾႃႉ ႁဵတ်း လႅၼ်း ထိူၼ်ႇ မၼုႁႃႇ ၼၢင်း မိူင်း ။
\notes  Pali loan word, from manuhara 'charming, captivating'
\dt  03/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜉𑜠 𑜆𑜀𑜫
\lxx  m; pkq
\ph  ma pak
\ps  n.
\ge  pumpkin
\de  pumpkin
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B185
\xe  𑜒𑜧 𑜉𑜠𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜒𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜋𑜥 𑜑𑜥 𑜒𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜁𑜠 𑜒𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜒𑜧 𑜃𑜪𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜦𑜧 𑜋𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  A] m;pkq A] nM cU hU A] nM x; A] nM fE[q A] nMvE[q el] citq xi[q citq xi[q a
\xn  av ma pak av nam chu hu av nam kha av nam phvng av nam thvng le chit khing chit khing
\xr  'pumpkins, cow's milk, 'kha' water, honey and curd; in two sets each set having seven things'
\xv 
\notes  Terwiel and Ranoo note that 'pumpikin' in Shan is <mak pak> with reference to Cushing p469. This example begins with the words <au
 ma> which might mean 'bring' (literally 'take come'). Alternatively
 the reading of <ma pak> 'suggests that <ma> is a short form of the
 word <mak> 'fruit'. This form is found in the Tai languages still
 spoken in Assam, like Phake and Aiton.
\dt  03/Aug/2011

\xn  nau khap pha nau dang nau kang nau khin nau chang nau (ka) nyot nau ma

\lx  𑜉𑜣

\gv  မီး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 4v5
\xe  𑜉𑜣 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜉𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜧 𑜄𑜠 𑜍𑜠 𑜏𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜋𑜡 𑜽
\xex  mI t[q t[q n[q mE[q nimq xi[q p] t; r; sitq ca /
\xn  mi tang nang mvng nim khing pav ta ra sit cha 
\xr  'With the queen of the country, of quite body who holds firmly to the laws and truth.'
\xv 
\gn  မီး တင်း ၼၢင်း မိူင်း ၼိမ် ၶိင်း ပႂ်ႉ တြႃး သႅတ်ႈၸႃႇ ။
\sn  2
\ge  rich
\de  to be rich
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မီး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 8v4
\xe  𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜊𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜣 𑜽
\xex  mEnq fa pEnq y[q co] pinq mI /
\xn  mvn pha pvn jang chau pin mi

\xv 
\gn  မိုၼ်ႇ ၾႃႉ ပိူၼ်ႈ ယင်း ၸဝ်ႈ ပဵၼ် မီး ။

\xex  2 xEw epa xunq mE[q k]w cM xiNq eta em] xoM co] kunq fo[q pju sEw /

\xr  '(The father said), The two of you, the princes of my country, please use the correct the words to order the minister to go and buy (her in
 marriage).'
\xv 
\gn  သွင် ၶိူဝ် ပေႃႈ ၶုၼ် မိူင်း ၵဝ် ၸမ်း ၶႅၼ်းတေႃႈ မႄး ၵႂၢမ်း ၸႂ်ႉ ၵူၼ်းၽွင်း ပႆ သိုဝ်ႉ ။
\sn  3
\ge  prepare
\de  to prepare
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႄး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 6r4
\xe  𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜩𑜨 𑜁𑜪 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜇𑜝𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  em] t[q coj xM siNq hitq fRkq /
\xn  me tang choi kham sen hit phrak
\xr  'To prepare the clean golden lady so that she makes a bamboo floor.'
\xv 
\gn  မႄး တင်း ၸွႆႉ ၶမ်း သႅၼ်ႈ ႁဵတ်း ၾၢၵ်ႈ ။

\dt  04/Aug/2011

\xex  xo] c[q xnq si[q rU[q si[q b[q mj /

\xv

\de  tree
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xex  mI t[q mj siNq lM fEw lkq eka hnq t[q rj xM pu[q y[q q bo] lEmq /
\xn  mi tang mai sin lam phv lak ko han tang rai kham pung jang jang bau lvm 
\xr  'With a 100,000 trees of different foliage, seeing a golden banyan tree, shooting up and shaking, looking good and smooth.'
\xv 
\gn  မီး တင်း မႆႉ သႅၼ် လမ်း ၽိူဝ် လၢၵ်ႇ ၵေႃႈ ႁၼ် တင်း ႁႆး ၶမ်း ပူင်ႇ ယင်ယင် ဝၢဝ်း လိူမ်ႈ ။
\se  𑜉𑜩𑜤
\sex  mju
\ge  tree
\de  tree
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႆႉ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 12r1
\xe  𑜉𑜣 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜩𑜤 𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  mI t[q mEnq cEw mju pinq bokq kinq bnq /
\xn  mi tang mvn chv maai pin bok kin ban 
\xr  'With 10,000 types of trees that have sweet fruits to eat.'
\xv 
\gn  မီး တင်း မိုၼ်ႇ ၸိူဝ်ႉ မႆႉ ပဵၼ် မၢၵ်ႇ ၵိၼ် ဝၢၼ် ။
\sn  3
\ge  bamboo
\de  bamboo
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 7r-17
\dn  𑜈𑜠 𑜑𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  b; hokq
\dr  ba hok
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  မႆႉ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 1v5
\xe  𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜩 𑜒𑜦𑜡 𑜈𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜪 𑜽
\xex  epa n[q mj eAa bokq liw lM /
\xn  po nang mai o bok liu lam 
\xr  'Like the single arundo bamboo blooming as a single trunk.'
\xv 
\gn  ပေႃး ၼင်ႇ မႆႉ ဢေႃႈလေႃး မွၵ်ႇ လဵဝ် လမ်း ။
\notes  The literal meaning of mai is 'wood', even though it is translated as 'bamboo' in the Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 7r-17. The
 example at Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 1v5 shows its use to refer to bamboo.

\xv 
\notes  /phu tu ku la/ means 'a kind of red flower'
\dt  03/Aug/2011

\xr  'He orders that the clouds high up be pulled in .... looking at the prince riding a diamond ox with two branches horns.'
\xv 
\gn  မၼ်း ယင်း သင်ႇ ၸၼ် မွၵ်ႇ ပွမ် လူမ်း မႃး (မြႃး?) (ႁႃး) (မိတ်း) (သႃ) လူ ၵေႃႈ ၶိင်း ၶုၼ် ၶီႇ တင်း ဝူဝ်း သႅင် ၶဝ် ၶႃႈ ။
\notes 
\dt  05/Aug/2011

\hm  2
\ps  n.
\ge  mulberry
\de  mulberry
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 35r-16
\dn  𑜃𑜥 𑜃𑜣𑜀𑜫
\dnx  nU nIkq
\dr  nu nik
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1v2
\xe  𑜏𑜧 𑜇𑜝𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜽
\xex  s] fRnq monq ec] nM /
\xn  sav phran mon che nam
\xr  'We put the seeds of the mulberry to soak in the water.'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  05/Aug/2011

\xv

\ph  mui

\gr

\xex  pi[q eta muNq no[q tu[q siNq rnq /
\xn  ping to mui nong tung sen ran
\xr  'Equal to the fog floating everywhere, to thousands of levels.'

\xv

\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xn  jin nang nam mui khon

\xr  'The prince of the country heard the murmur of them calling and barking, and the sound of them enjoying, echoing up to the level of

\sex  foa;
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၽႃ

\xex  pI hnq tI fukonq lu[q lnq fIma eka pEnq h] tj sI a

\lx  𑜇𑜥 𑜏𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜍𑜄𑜫
\lxx  fU stq k; rtq
\ph  phu sat ka rat
\ps  n.
\ge  ?
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 56v-13
\dn  𑜈𑜠 𑜃𑜄𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜆𑜤𑜍𑜫
\dnx  b; ntq k; purq
\dr  ba nat ka pur
\dv 
\gr 
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Tileswar Mohan says /ko boj ka pur/ means 'shield like dress worn by soldier'. However, Junaram Phukan said /phu/ meaning 'male' and /sat ka rat/ meaning
 'dress worn by actors in drama'
\dt  16/Aug/2011

\de  kind of vegetable, a
\so  Loti Amra; (Prem Phukon); 12r-13
\dn  𑜏𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  snq nokq
\dr  san no-k
\dv 
\gr 
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv 
\notes  Ahom Lexicon, p 174 /phak ki la/ is given, with the meaning 'a kind of vegetable'
\dt  13/Aug/2011

\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4r3

\xe  𑜑𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜤𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜑𑜪𑜨 𑜉𑜠 𑜃𑜥 𑜍𑜠 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜤𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜈𑜡 𑜇𑜣𑜰𑜫𑜤 𑜁𑜨𑜆𑜫 𑜽
\xex  hnq t[q nu[qu hoM m; nU r; eka k>[q siNq ba fIwu xopq /

\xn  khv song ra ko nyang chong kin tang khong phrak chau khai pha tham au 
\xr  '(The two officers said), We two senior ones then wholeheartedly received the things which we will present to the betrothed of the

\lx  𑜌𑜐𑜫
\lxx  vNq
\ph  thai
\hm  4
\ps  v.
\ge  ?
\de  ?
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 47r-18
\dn  𑜉𑜠 𑜋𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜎𑜡 𑜈𑜨𑜍𑜫

\gr 
\rf 
\xe 
\xn 
\xr 
\xv

 'to comb the hair'

\ph  then
\ps  n.

\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A1
\xe  𑜊𑜪𑜣  𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜃𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜐𑜫𑜁𑜪 𑜋𑜪 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜪 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜩 𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜫𑜰𑜫 𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜇𑜡 ..
\xex  yM I mEw li[qnonq viNqxM cM s[q ninq s[q nM s[q lj s[q pqw Aokq fa ..
\xn  yim mu'w ling non then kham cham sang nin sang nam sang lai sang pau ok pha ...
\xr  'In the beginning after Lengdon and Thaen Kham had established the earth, water and fire in the world ...'
\xv

\notes 
\dt  29/Aug/2011

\ph  thiu

\de  pure silver
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr

\xe  𑜋𑜪𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜐𑜧 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜁𑜪 𑜒𑜧 𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜽

\xn  cham chang tak pha ko nyav chau khun thiu kham av ok

 means 'bright'

\ge  word
\de  word
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv 
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 7r7

\xex  voj s[q xjfa em] poj m; /
\xn  thoi sang khai pha me poi ma
\xr  '(The mother said), Oh my son the novice king, you have come.'
\xv 
\gn  ထွႆႈ (သၢင်ႇ) ၶႆႇၾႃႉ မႄႈ ပွႆး မႃး ။
\notes  The word 'thoi' is sometimes used in a four syllable expression in combination with 'khom/khwam'. In the example from Nemi Mang;
 ; 7r7, it is not translated but conveys the fact that these are the
 words of the mother.

\xe  𑜏𑜂𑜫 𑜇𑜟𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜃𑜧𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜉𑜠 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜩 𑜉𑜠 𑜋𑜃𑜫 𑜀𑜥 𑜇𑜣 𑜎𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  s[q e?a si[qu no]w m; vE[q kunq sj m; cnq kU fI linq /
\xn  sang phro seng nau ma thvng kun sai ma chan ku phi lin 
\xr  'The ship of the diamond star came and reached the sand island, pulled to the bed of the earth spirit.'
\xv 
\gn  သၢင်းၽေႃး သႅင် လၢဝ် မႃး ထိုင် ၵုၼ် သၢႆး မႃး ၸၼ် ၵူႇ ၽီ (လိၼ်) ။
\se  𑜏𑜩𑜤
\sex  sju
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သၢႆး
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 13r7
\xe  𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜧 𑜒𑜧𑜨 𑜏𑜩𑜤 𑜍𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜃𑜪 𑜄𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜽
\xex  xunq mE[q h] Ao] sju rinq lu[q konq nM tukq /
\xn  khun mvng hav au saai rin lung kon nam tuk 
\xr  'The prince of the country first made (the servants) bring down the sand and stone to the water fall.'
\xv 
\gn  ၶုၼ် မိူင်း ႁႂ်ႈ ဢဝ် သၢႆး ႁိၼ် လူင်း ၵွၼ်ႇ ၼမ်ႉ တူၵ်း ။
\notes  Also at Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 9r-16
\dt  22/Aug/2011

\dr  pu bot re nu u lu ak

\gr

\xe  𑜒𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜩 𑜄𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜱 𑜑𑜢𑜫𑜡 𑜏𑜪𑜤 𑜃𑜩𑜨 𑜲 𑜁𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  Aw t[q mj tunq 1 hiqa suM noj 2 x[q riunq /
\xn  au tang mai tun lvng hit sum noi song khang rvn
\xr  'He cut a tree and built a small shelter, a two sided house.'
\xv

\dt  26/Aug/2011

\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B115
\xe  𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜏𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜡 𑜍𑜦𑜡 𑜎𑜧𑜍𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜎𑜧 𑜇𑜝𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜀𑜫𑜉𑜥 𑜉𑜧 𑜆𑜥 𑜉𑜀𑜫 𑜇𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜂𑜫𑜀𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜏𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜀𑜤𑜐𑜫 𑜁𑜢𑜰𑜫𑜫 𑜀𑜩 𑜁𑜩 𑜒𑜩𑜨 𑜋𑜪 𑜼
\xex  xo] snq ha era l]rEw l] fRnq mkqmU m] pU mkq fitq xi[qki[q kuNq sukq kuNq xiwq kj xj Aoj cM a
\xn  khau san ha ro lav rv lav phran mak mu mav pu mak phit khing king kui suk kui khiu kai khai oi cham
\xr  'five bundles of husked rice, strong drink, distilled liquor, areca nuts, betel leaves, chillies, ginger, ripe bananas, green bananas, chickens,
 eggs and sugar cane'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  26/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜏𑜨𑜀𑜫
\lxx  sokq
\ph  sok
\hm  2
\ps  n.
\ge  elbow
\de  elbow, also used as a measure of length from the elbow to the tip of tmiddle finger
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 22r-7
\dn  𑜀𑜣 𑜎𑜡 𑜀𑜨𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜣𑜀𑜫
\dnx  kI la kow tIkq
\dr  ki la ku tik
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သွၵ်ႇ
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 12v7
\xe  𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜁𑜧 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜠 𑜄𑜥 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜑𑜡 𑜏𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜨𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜠 𑜋𑜪 𑜽
\xex  pju x] xEw k; tU c[q ha sokq sonq [; cM /
\xn  pai khav khv ka tu chang ha sok son nga cham 
\xr  'The end of the horn is about as big as the cubit length tusks of five elephants placed one upon the other.'
\xv 
\gn  ပၢႆ ၶဝ် ၶိူဝ်ႈ ၵႃႈ တူဝ် ၸၢင်ႉ ႁႃႈ သွၵ်ႇ သွၼ်ႉ ငႃး ၸမ်း ။
\notes  Also at Loti Amra; (Prem Phukon); 4r-4, where it is spelled 'ki la kau tik'
\dt  25/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫
\lxx  si[q
\ph  sing
\hm  8
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  end
\de  to end; to finish
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သဵင်ႈ
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4r8
\xe  𑜏𑜥 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜩 𑜀𑜢𑜃𑜫 𑜆𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜣 𑜄𑜩 𑜎𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜃𑜪 𑜑𑜠 𑜽
\xex  sU c[q nj kinq pkq sikq si[q sI tj lE[q et] nM h; /
\xn  su chang nai kin pak sik sing si tai lvng te nam vi
\xr  'You will then get to eat until your mouth is torn and then die, oh.'
\xv 
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  finish
\de  to finish
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သဵင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 7r3
\xe  𑜈𑜡 𑜀𑜠 𑜃𑜩 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  ba k; nj si[q knq /
\xn  ba ka nai sing kan
\xr  'And say like this, it was all finished.'
\xv 
\gn  ဝႃႈ ၵႃႈ ၼႆႉ သဵင်ႈ ၵၼ် ။
\sn  3
\ge  used.up
\de  to be used up
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သဵင်ႈ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 4r6
\xe  𑜀𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  ko[q eta n[q k[q co] epa si[q /
\xn  kong to nang kang chau po sing
\xr  'And like this (they wanted to present all the things) their hearts desired until they were used up.'
\xv 
\gn  ၵွင်းတေႃႈ ၼင်ႇ ၵၢင် ၸႂ် ပေႃး သဵင်ႈ ။
\notes  In the example, the phrase <sik sing si tai> is literally 'tear end PRT die', which could be rendered 'torn so that it ends and then die'
\dt  25/Aug/2011

\xex  njeka mEw Anq si[q no]w co] Ai[q ko[qbU so[q mq[q  rEw fa /
\xn  nai ko mv an sing nau chau ing kong bu song mang mang rv pha 
\xr  'Moreover, at that time the diamond star (king) was leaning on the gloriously bright pagoda in the sky.'
\xv 
\gn  ၼႆႉၵေႃႈ မိူဝ်ႈ ဢၼ် သႅင် လၢဝ် ၸဝ်ႈ ဢိင် ၵွင်းမူး သွင်ႇ မင်းမင်း ႁိူဝ်ႈ ၾႃႉ ။
\se  𑜲
\sex  2
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သွင်ႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 14v5
\xe  𑜂𑜧 𑜲 𑜇𑜡 𑜋𑜪𑜨 𑜈𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜽
\xex  [] 2 fa coM bunq /
\xn  ngav song pha chom bun
\xr  'Shading (for others) the brightness of the sky from the summit of heaven.'
\xv 
\gn  ငဝ်း သွင်ႇ ၾႃႉ ၸွမ် မုၼ် ။
\se  𑜏𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤
\sex  so[qu
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သွင်ႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 11r2
\xe  𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜨𑜂𑜫𑜤 𑜇𑜡 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  epa n[q bnq so[qu fa tkq ti[q /
\xn  po nang ban song pha tak ting
\xr  'Like the bright day, the midday sky.'
\xv 
\gn  ပေႃး ၼင်ႇ ဝၼ်း သွင်ႇ ၾႃႉ တၵ်း တဵင်ႈ ။
\sn  2
\se  𑜏𑜨𑜂𑜫
\sex  so[q
\ge  shine
\de  to shine
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  သွင်ႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 9v3
\xe  𑜃𑜥 𑜋𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜍𑜃𑜫 𑜑𑜦𑜪𑜡 𑜁𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜉𑜧 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜏𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜪𑜤 𑜇𑜡 𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜎𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  nU cEnq [iunq rnq ehaM xiNq m] eka so[q ruM fa epa lE[q /
\xn  nu chvn ngvn ran ho kham khen mav ko song rum pha po lvng 
\xr  'Looking golden yellow, the levels of the palace were newer and shined covering the sky until all was yellow.'
\xv 
\gn  လူ ၸိုၼ်းငိုၼ်း ႁၢၼ်ႉ ႁေႃၶမ်း ၶႅၼ်း မႂ်ႇ ၵေႃႈ သွင်ႇ ႁူမ်ႇ ၾႃႉ ပေႃး လိူင် ။

\xex  mnq y[q 2 tU fa s[q b[q /

\xv 
\gn  မၼ်း ယင်း သွင်ႇ တူဝ်ႈ ၾႃႉ သၢင်းဝၢင်း ။

\notes  Also at Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 36r-9, where it is spelled 'dho ro mok', and at Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan);
 57r-11, where it is spelled 'tho ro mok'
\dt  24/Aug/2011

\dv

\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 5v7
\xe  𑜒𑜧 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜧 𑜀𑜂𑜫 𑜌𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜐𑜨𑜄𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜽

 put into the laopani or Ahom liquor.

\dnx  hojNq nokq
\dr  hoen nok
\dv 
\gr 
\rf  Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B68
\xe  𑜀𑜪 𑜈𑜃𑜫𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜎𑜥 𑜄𑜀𑜫 𑜆𑜂𑜫 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜤 𑜎𑜤𑜀𑜫 𑜋𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜩 𑜼
\xex  kM bnqAokq cM tkq lU tkq p[q lukq siu lukq co[q eka rj a
\xn  kam ban ok cham tak lu tak pang luk siu luk chong ko rai
\xr  'If it comes out in the east there will be ruin and destruction and soldiers will die'
\xv 
\notes 
\dt  25/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜏𑜢𑜰𑜫

\sn  2
\ge  sickle
\de  sickle
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ၶဵဝ်း (သဵဝ်း)
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 11r3
\xe  𑜄𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜰𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜋𑜪𑜤 𑜑𑜩 𑜄𑜦𑜧𑜪 𑜽
\xex  tEw siw t[q mE[q cuM hj et]M /
\xn  tv siu tang mvng chum hai te jav
\xr  'Use the sickle so that all the country rejoice in the upland field.'
\xv 
\gn  တိုဝ်း ၶဵဝ်း တင်း မိူင်း ၸူမ်း ႁႆႈ တႄႉယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes  Chaichuen Khamdaengyodtai pointed out that although this word was written 'kheu' in Shan, it could be pronounced 'seu' in speech
\dt  25/Aug/2011

\gr

\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 8r1
\xe  𑜲 𑜁𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜁𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜀𑜧𑜰𑜫 𑜋𑜪 𑜁𑜢𑜐𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜁𑜪𑜨 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜀𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜇𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜤 𑜏𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜽
\xex  2 xEw epa xunq mE[q k]w cM xiNq eta em] xoM co] kunq fo[q pju sEw /
\xn  song khv po khun mvng kau cham khen to me khom chau kun phong paai sv 
\xr  '(The father said), The two of you, the princes of my country, please use the correct the words to order the minister to go and buy (her in
 marriage).'
\xv 
\gn  သွင် ၶိူဝ် ပေႃႈ ၶုၼ် မိူင်း ၵဝ် ၸမ်း ၶႅၼ်းတေႃႈ မႄး ၵႂၢမ်း ၸႂ်ႉ ၵူၼ်းၽွင်း ပႆ သိုဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  22/Jul/2011

\xe  𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜒𑜃𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜀𑜰𑜫 𑜆𑜧𑜪 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜄𑜦𑜡 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜡 𑜍𑜩 𑜁𑜪 𑜽
\xex  mEw Anq cw kw p]M co] eta t[q mEnq xa rj xM /
\xn  mv an chau kau pem chau to tang mvn kha rai kham 
\xr  'At that time my Lord was delighted in his mind with these ornaments like the tribute of slaves, common people and gold.'
\xv 
\gn  မိူဝ်ႈ ဢၼ် ၸဝ်ႈ ၵဝ် ပဵမ်ႇ ၸႂ် တေႃႇ တၢင်းမႆ မိူၼ် ၶႃႈ ႁၢႆး ၶမ်း ။
\sn  3
\ge  tribute
\de  tribute, tax
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ႁႆၢး
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 5v6
\xe  𑜑𑜧 𑜆𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜄𑜧 𑜏𑜣 𑜏𑜥𑜐𑜫 𑜄𑜣 𑜉𑜧 𑜽
\xex  h] pEnq t] sI sUNq tI m] /
\xn  hav pvn tav si sui ti mav
\xr  'And making others come to pay tribute to you.'
\xv 
\gn  ႁႂ်ႈ ပိူၼ်ႈ တဝ်ႈ သေ သူၺ်ႇ တီႈ မႂ်း ။

\xe  𑜁𑜆𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜏𑜪 𑜇𑜢𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜏𑜣 𑜍𑜦𑜡 𑜀𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 : 𑜏𑜣 𑜄𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜉𑜃𑜫 𑜂𑜠 : 𑜏𑜣 𑜒𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜼
\xex  xpq fa sM fEnq xo] sI era kEw : sI tokq mnq [; : sI Ai[q a
\xn  khap pha sam phvn khau si ro kv sip si tok man nga sip si ing
\xr  'three small mats, four bundles of rice, fourteen toks of salt, fourteen pots of sesame oil'
\xv 
\gn 
\sn  2
\ge  wrap
\de  to wrap
\so 
\dn

\gv  ႁေႃႇ
\rf  Nemi Mang; ; 2r5

\xex  xM ni[q tkq ba n]w n[q lU puM la era fa /
\xn  kham ning tak ba nau nang lu pum la ro  pha 
\xr  'The red gold king will come and pull the lady, gazing at her wide abdomen (to get her to be) wrapped in clothes.'

\xe  𑜆𑜢𑜃𑜫𑜂𑜫 𑜃𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜦𑜧 𑜒𑜨𑜀𑜫 𑜇𑜡 𑜀𑜦𑜡 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜩𑜨 𑜍𑜢𑜀𑜫 𑜄𑜂𑜫 𑜒𑜠 𑜉𑜄𑜫 𑜌𑜧𑜨 𑜉𑜠 𑜃𑜦𑜧 (/)
\xex  pinq[q n[q mE[q em] Aokq fa eka c[q poj rikq t[q A; mtq vo] m; en] (/)
\xn  pin nang nang mvng me ok pha ko chang poi rik tang a mat thau ma ne 
\xr  'And like this the lady of the country, the mother who came from the sky, called the old ministers to come and show.'
\xv 
\gn  ပဵၼ်ၼင်ႇ ၼၢင်း မိူင်း မႄႈ ဢွၵ်ႇ ၾႃႉ ၵေႃႈ ၸင်ႇ ပွႆး ႁဵၵ်ႈ တင်း ဢမၢတ်ႈ ထဝ်ႈ မႃး ၼႄ (။)

\dt  19/Aug/2011

\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4v5
\xe  𑜈𑜤𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜦𑜧 𑜇𑜠 𑜒𑜧 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜰𑜫 𑜑𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜪𑜫 𑜑𑜢𑜄𑜫 𑜋𑜰𑜫 𑜽
\xex  buo[q et] f; A] mEw eha ru[q xMQ hitq cw /
\xn  bong te pha au mvw ho rung kham hit chau
\xr  'Emperor who created the universe (will) take him and go to the palace of the golden throne and make him a king.'
\xv 
\gn 
\notes 
\dt  21/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  ru[q
\ph  rung
\hm  7
\ps  v.
\ge  famous
\de  famous, to be
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ႁူင်
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 3v5
\xe  𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜈𑜃𑜫 𑜉𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜦𑜡 𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜽
\xex  si[q xnq bnq mE[q pi[q epa ru[q /
\xn  sing khan ban mvng ping po rung
\xr  'The sweet sound of their crowing is spread out over the country until family.'
\xv 
\xe 
\sn  2
\ge  spread.fame
\de  spread fame, to; be famous, to
\so 
\dn 
\dr 
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ႁူင်
\rf  Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 3v1
\xe  𑜁𑜧𑜨 𑜋𑜂𑜫 𑜁𑜃𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜍𑜥𑜂𑜫 𑜏𑜢𑜂𑜫 𑜈𑜂𑜫 𑜉𑜩 𑜽
\xex  xo] c[q xnq si[q rU[q si[q b[q mj /
\xn  khau chang khan sing rung sing bang mai
\xr  'They crowed their sound throughout the forest.'
\xv 
\xe 
\gv 
\notes  The phrase <khan sing rung sing> is literally 'crowed their sound and spread the fame of their sound ...'
\dt  21/Aug/2011

\lx  𑜍𑜤𑜂𑜫

\xex  h] tI cw ema rU emoa si[q cM tI x] h] ru[q kinq a
\xn  hav ti chau mo ru mo sing cham ti khav hav rung kin
\xr  'give to the knowledgeable and enlightened ones, to them give prepared food'
\xv 
\notes  In the example, the phrase <hav rung kin> means literally 'give them to boil and eat'

\lx  𑜍𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫
\lxx  rE[q
\ph  rvng
\hm  3
\ps  n.
\ge  long.time
\de  a long time; many days
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 29r-18
\dn  𑜒𑜦𑜡 𑜔𑜣𑜀𑜫 𑜓𑜣 𑜃𑜦𑜨𑜀𑜫
\dnx  eAa DIkq dI enokq
\dr  o dhik di nok
\dv 
\gr 
\gv  ႁိုင်
\rf  Pvn Ko Mvng; ; 17r7
\xe  𑜏𑜧 𑜍𑜢𑜤𑜂𑜫 𑜆𑜤𑜃𑜫 𑜎𑜩 𑜁𑜤𑜆𑜫 𑜊𑜣 𑜋𑜧𑜨 𑜀𑜤𑜨𑜂𑜫 𑜄𑜊𑜦𑜧 𑜽
\xex  s] rE[q punq lj xupq yI co] kuo[q ety] /
\xn  sav rvng pun lai khup ji chau kwang te jav 
\xr  'He rests there a long time, passing many years in the place of very large wide granaries.'
\xv 
\gn  သဝ်း ႁုိင် ပူၼ်ႉ လၢႆ ၶူပ်ႇ ယေး ၸဝ်ႈ ၵႂၢင်ႈ တႄႉယဝ်ႉ ။
\notes 
\dt  15/Jun/2011

\ph  run
\hm  4
\ps  v.
\sn  1
\ge  grow
\de  to grow
\so  Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 36v-17
\dn  𑜕𑜍𑜫 𑜊𑜣 𑜈𑜨𑜍

\dr  gar ji bor
